title: Sustainable Growth and Inequality – Final Exam Prep

questions.questionText: In this course, what definition of sustainable growth would withstand both technical scrutiny and political debate?
options: Growth is sustainable whenever inflation is low, regardless of distribution or environmental damage.
Sustainable growth means per-capita income rises in a way that remains socially and environmentally viable by widening access to opportunities and cushioning adjustment costs.
Any period with a current-account surplus counts as sustainable growth by definition.
If the fiscal budget is balanced, resource depletion and rising inequality do not affect sustainability.
questions.correctAnswer: Sustainable growth means per-capita income rises in a way that remains socially and environmentally viable by widening access to opportunities and cushioning adjustment costs.
questions.explanation: Durability requires legitimacy and stewardship: broad participation in gains and credible protection for those exposed to transition risks.

questions.questionText: Within the Solow model with exogenous technological progress, which interpretation accounts for persistent income differences across countries without contradicting the model?
options: A permanently higher saving rate guarantees a permanently higher per-worker growth rate.
Differences in effective technology and efficiency drive persistent income gaps; saving and population growth mainly shift steady-state levels rather than long-run per-worker growth.
Population growth alone sets the steady-state capital–labor ratio, so demographics fully explain cross-country income gaps.
Average tariff protection alters depreciation and thus explains most income differences even when technology is identical.
questions.correctAnswer: Differences in effective technology and efficiency drive persistent income gaps; saving and population growth mainly shift steady-state levels rather than long-run per-worker growth.
questions.explanation: With diminishing returns, capital deepening moves levels; sustained per-worker growth is pinned down by technological progress (TFP).

questions.questionText: When diagnosing why a country remains poor, how does the course distinguish proximate from fundamental causes in a way that guides policy?
options: Capital and schooling are fundamental because they last many years, while institutions and disease ecology are proximate.

Capital, skills, and total factor productivity act directly on output and are proximate; institutions and geography are fundamental because they shape incentives and the feasibility of accumulating those proximate drivers.
Trade openness and foreign investment are fundamental, whereas culture is a proximate artifact of recent policy.
Only geography is fundamental; institutions are proximate because constitutions can be rewritten quickly.
questions.correctAnswer: Capital, skills, and total factor productivity act directly on output and are proximate; institutions and geography are fundamental because they shape incentives and the feasibility of accumulating those proximate drivers.
questions.explanation: Fundamentals govern the long-run accumulation and allocation of proximate inputs and the rules under which they are used.

questions.questionText: According to the Acemoglu–Johnson–Robinson framework, what is the specific mechanism by which inclusive institutions raise long-run growth?
options: They fix capital taxes at zero, which maximizes investment regardless of politics.
They broaden secure property rights and market access so new entrants can invest and innovate without fear of arbitrary expropriation, enabling creative destruction even against incumbent resistance.
They guarantee equal post-tax incomes via large transfers, and redistribution alone explains growth accelerations.
They protect firms from foreign competition behind permanent tariffs to build scale safely.
questions.correctAnswer: They broaden secure property rights and market access so new entrants can invest and innovate without fear of arbitrary expropriation, enabling creative destruction even against incumbent resistance.
questions.explanation: Credible constraints on arbitrary power allow potential innovators outside the elite to challenge incumbents and reallocate resources productively.

questions.questionText: Rodrik, Subramanian, and Trebbi compare institutions, geography, and trade using instrumental variables. Which reading is most faithful to their identification strategy and the pattern of coefficients?
options: Geography mechanically determines income; once latitude and disease are included, institutions add only noise.

After addressing endogeneity, institutional quality explains a large share of income variation; geography mainly matters through its imprint on institutions; and the direct effects of simple openness measures weaken once institutions are included.
Trade shares cause institutional reform everywhere, and reform subsequently determines a country’s latitude and disease burden.
Institutional indices mostly proxy schooling; adding human capital eliminates institutions’ role.
questions.correctAnswer: After addressing endogeneity, institutional quality explains a large share of income variation; geography mainly matters through its imprint on institutions; and the direct effects of simple openness measures weaken once institutions are included.
questions.explanation: The causal weight falls on institutions after purging reverse causality, with geography operating largely through institutional channels.

questions.questionText: In the Atlantic trade narrative, how did external commercial opportunities translate into institutional change and later industrialization in parts of Western Europe?
options: Trade windfalls automatically induced reform everywhere, regardless of initial political conditions.

Atlantic trade empowered merchant groups; where some pluralist checks already existed, they secured stronger constraints on rulers and more reliable property rights, which later supported broad investment and industrialization.
Atlantic trade mainly increased royal rents in England and entrenched absolutism.
Atlantic trade mattered only by reducing inland transport costs for agriculture; politics was irrelevant.
questions.correctAnswer: Atlantic trade empowered merchant groups; where some pluralist checks already existed, they secured stronger constraints on rulers and more reliable property rights, which later supported broad investment and industrialization.
questions.explanation: Trade interacted with initial pluralism to shift political power and secure broad property rights that encouraged investment.

questions.questionText: In several Latin American liberalizations, wage inequality increased even though endowment logic suggested the opposite. Which mechanism best fits the micro evidence from Mexico and Colombia?
options: Trade reform reduced competition, allowing low-skill unions to extract rents and widen dispersion.
Import competition and foreign direct investment induced within-industry upgrading and more skill-intensive techniques, raising the relative demand for skilled labor inside liberalizing sectors.
Tariff cuts erased migration barriers, collapsing local wage gaps and mechanically raising national inequality even as skill premia fell.
Land reform changed measured asset inequality and drove urban wage trends.
questions.correctAnswer: Import competition and foreign direct investment induced within-industry upgrading and more skill-intensive techniques, raising the relative demand for skilled labor inside liberalizing sectors.
questions.explanation: Plant-level evidence shows skill-biased technological change within industries after reform, not only reallocation across industries.

questions.questionText: When previously protected plants respond to tariff cuts by adopting advanced machinery and hiring more skilled workers, what does this imply about the link from trade to inequality?
options: All plants converge to a single technology, which eliminates the skill premium.
Within-sector skill-biased technological change connects openness to higher relative demand for skills; inequality can rise even without large across-sector shifts.
Tariff cuts move workers instantly from agriculture to manufacturing with no transitional wage pressure.
Multinationals always reduce returns to education because they offshore only low-skill tasks.
questions.correctAnswer: Within-sector skill-biased technological change connects openness to higher relative demand for skills; inequality can rise even without large across-sector shifts.
questions.explanation: Upgrading inside industries reconciles data with comparative advantage at the country level.

questions.questionText: Which mechanism most plausibly explains how high inequality today can depress the next generation’s growth rate?
options: Higher inequality raises aggregate saving and therefore guarantees faster capital accumulation.

Binding credit and education constraints exclude able households from acquiring skills or starting firms, producing underinvestment in human capital and entrepreneurship and lowering aggregate productivity growth.
High inequality shrinks government mechanically and thus raises productivity by cutting administrative costs.
Concentrated income weakens elite control over courts, so innovation blocking falls and growth accelerates.
questions.correctAnswer: Binding credit and education constraints exclude able households from acquiring skills or starting firms, producing underinvestment in human capital and entrepreneurship and lowering aggregate productivity growth.
questions.explanation: Opportunity constraints link distribution to dynamic efficiency through human capital and firm formation.

questions.questionText: Easterly and coauthors instrument long-run inequality with historical crop suitability. What structural channel are they trying to identify, and why does it still matter?
options: Plantation crops favored coercive large-scale production that entrenched inequality and extractive institutions, whose effects on investment and governance persist.
Plantation crops guaranteed inclusive institutions because scale required universal education.
Crop patterns determine contemporary rainfall, which directly fixes income regardless of institutions.
Crop patterns only affected historical farm profits and left no institutional legacy.
questions.correctAnswer: Plantation crops favored coercive large-scale production that entrenched inequality and extractive institutions, whose effects on investment and governance persist.
questions.explanation: Endowments shaped political power and institutional trajectories, leaving persistent effects on modern development.

questions.questionText: How should a finance minister communicate Dollar and Kraay’s claim that growth is good for the poor without overstating it?
options: Bottom-quintile income tends to track average income roughly one-for-one on average, so broad-based growth usually lifts poor households even if inequality does not always fall.
Growth invariably raises the bottom faster than the mean, so inequality almost always declines.
Growth largely bypasses poor households; redistribution is the only tool that affects poverty.
Bottom-quintile income is unrelated to mean growth, so macro strategy is irrelevant for poverty.
questions.correctAnswer: Bottom-quintile income tends to track average income roughly one-for-one on average, so broad-based growth usually lifts poor households even if inequality does not always fall.
questions.explanation: Their core result is proportionality on average—not automatic equality and not a claim that inequality necessarily narrows.

questions.questionText: Several studies show that the poverty-reducing effect of growth depends on initial inequality. What does this mean for sequencing reforms?
options: With the same growth rate, countries that start with higher inequality tend to see smaller poverty reductions because more gains accrue to households already above the line; improving opportunity equality raises the poverty elasticity of growth.
In countries with a Gini above thirty, growth and poverty are statistically unrelated, so redistribution is the only lever.
Higher inequality forces progressive taxation that accelerates poverty reduction automatically.
Once openness and the exchange-rate regime are controlled for, initial inequality ceases to matter for poverty.
questions.correctAnswer: With the same growth rate, countries that start with higher inequality tend to see smaller poverty reductions because more gains accrue to households already above the line; improving opportunity equality raises the poverty elasticity of growth.
questions.explanation: Initial distribution conditions the mapping from mean growth to poverty reduction; opportunity-expanding reforms strengthen that mapping.

questions.questionText: Why is it useful to distinguish inequality of opportunity from inequality of outcome when assessing long-run growth prospects?
options: Opportunity inequality refers to systematic exclusion from schooling, health, credit, and legal protection; it depresses human capital formation and institutional legitimacy and lowers future productivity growth.
Opportunity inequality captures only transitory consumption fluctuations during business cycles.
It is merely a different formula for the Gini coefficient that uses deciles instead of quintiles.
It refers exclusively to differences in post-tax income across age cohorts.
questions.correctAnswer: Opportunity inequality refers to systematic exclusion from schooling, health, credit, and legal protection; it depresses human capital formation and institutional legitimacy and lowers future productivity growth.
questions.explanation: Excluding groups from core inputs wastes talent and undermines trust in institutions that support investment.

questions.questionText: A government responds to import-driven job loss with broad tariffs. Which critique aligns with the course’s emphasis on inclusive openness and place-based policy?
options: Tariffs target comparative advantage directly and guarantee productivity growth by preventing reallocation.

Tariffs may slow layoffs but also raise prices, invite retaliation, and freeze obsolete structures; mobility support, retraining, and place-based investment help regions transition while preserving efficiency gains from openness.
Tariffs are irrelevant because workers move instantly at zero cost.
Tariffs raise average wages by raising import prices, which boosts profits and investment in the same plants.
questions.correctAnswer: Tariffs may slow layoffs but also raise prices, invite retaliation, and freeze obsolete structures; mobility support, retraining, and place-based investment help regions transition while preserving efficiency gains from openness.
questions.explanation: Insurance and mobility assistance address concentrated losses without sacrificing national efficiency.

questions.questionText: Why can wage insurance and mobility support dominate broad tariffs both economically and politically when import competition intensifies?
options: They restore each displaced worker’s prior wage indefinitely, eliminating political pressure.
They target concentrated losses among workers and regions while preserving national gains from openness, sustaining support for engagement rather than freezing structure with blanket protection.
They remove the need for unemployment insurance because all displaced workers quickly find higher-paying jobs.
They guarantee population growth in declining regions by attracting firms instantly.
questions.correctAnswer: They target concentrated losses among workers and regions while preserving national gains from openness, sustaining support for engagement rather than freezing structure with blanket protection.
questions.explanation: Compensating people, not sectors, maintains efficiency and the political coalition for openness.

questions.questionText: In the Bolivia case, why was institutional reform treated as a precondition for diversification rather than an add-on after infrastructure upgrades?
options: Institutions were already world-class, so additional reforms were purely cosmetic.

A landlocked location, high transport costs, and reliance on volatile resource rents raise the premium on credible property rights, predictable regulation, and operational state capacity; roads alone would not shift investor expectations toward non-extractive activity.
Geography is irrelevant, so tariff policy is the only lever that matters in the short run.
Reform aimed primarily to ban foreign ownership to accelerate technology transfer.
questions.correctAnswer: A landlocked location, high transport costs, and reliance on volatile resource rents raise the premium on credible property rights, predictable regulation, and operational state capacity; roads alone would not shift investor expectations toward non-extractive activity.
questions.explanation: Adverse geography and resource dependence make credibility complements to infrastructure for attracting long-horizon private investment.

questions.questionText: In the South Africa case, why can expanding access to quality education and basic services be characterized as a growth policy rather than a pure redistribution program?
options: Transfers raise total factor productivity by definition because spending equals productivity in growth accounting.
Broadening access to schooling and health expands human capital and strengthens labor-market attachment among historically excluded groups, increasing future productivity and the tax base.
Growth has already eliminated structural unemployment, so any distributional program is symbolic.
Redistribution has no meaningful macroeconomic effects in middle-income countries.
questions.correctAnswer: Broadening access to schooling and health expands human capital and strengthens labor-market attachment among historically excluded groups, increasing future productivity and the tax base.
questions.explanation: Opportunity-expanding redistribution is an investment in future capacity and social stability.

questions.questionText: During the pandemic, many emerging economies had limited fiscal space. Which causal chain best links inequality, thin safety nets, and debt vulnerabilities?
options: High inequality implies strong automatic stabilizers, so borrowing needs fell despite output collapses.
Where safety nets are thin, households and governments borrow to smooth large shocks; leverage rises and future fiscal space shrinks, reducing resilience even if the initial shock is cushioned.
High inequality guarantees investor confidence by concentrating wealth and lowering sovereign spreads.
Debt dynamics depend only on the current account, not on domestic insurance or political stability.
questions.correctAnswer: Where safety nets are thin, households and governments borrow to smooth large shocks; leverage rises and future fiscal space shrinks, reducing resilience even if the initial shock is cushioned.
questions.explanation: Leverage is a substitute for insurance; its accumulation constrains future macro policy.

questions.questionText: Designing inclusive green growth requires attention to both efficiency and distribution. Which package best meets that goal in a politically durable way?
options: Adopt a uniform carbon tax and use all revenue to cut profit taxes because investment incentives dominate distribution.
Adopt a clear carbon price and recycle part of the revenue into targeted household transfers, mobility support, and place-based transition investment in carbon-intensive regions.
Ban high-emitting sectors immediately without compensation to maximize the speed of adjustment.
Rely only on voluntary corporate pledges to avoid short-run energy price increases.
questions.correctAnswer: Adopt a clear carbon price and recycle part of the revenue into targeted household transfers, mobility support, and place-based transition investment in carbon-intensive regions.
questions.explanation: Pairing price signals with cushioning preserves abatement incentives and social consent for decarbonization.

questions.questionText: Why does the course treat state capacity as a productive input rather than a mere governance nicety, and how does this shape private investment?
options: High state capacity removes the need for property rights because the state can plan production directly.
Effective states enforce contracts, collect taxes predictably, deliver services at scale, and respond credibly in crises, lowering uncertainty and transaction costs for private investors.
High state capacity guarantees immediate equality, so investors can ignore governance when valuing risk.
High state capacity makes market prices irrelevant because procurement can offset any signal.
questions.correctAnswer: Effective states enforce contracts, collect taxes predictably, deliver services at scale, and respond credibly in crises, lowering uncertainty and transaction costs for private investors.
questions.explanation: Implementation credibility complements private capital and expands the set of viable long-horizon projects.

questions.questionText: Why can ideas sustain long-run growth in endogenous models, whereas additional physical capital alone cannot once an economy nears its steady state?
options: Ideas depreciate more slowly than machines, so growth rises mechanically when investment is steady.
Ideas are non-rival and scalable, and knowledge spillovers prevent the marginal payoff to new ideas from collapsing the way the marginal product of rival capital does.
Ideas require autarky to diffuse, so closed economies grow faster than open ones.
Ideas are rival inputs owned by single firms, so monopoly profits always finance research fully.
questions.correctAnswer: Ideas are non-rival and scalable, and knowledge spillovers prevent the marginal payoff to new ideas from collapsing the way the marginal product of rival capital does.
questions.explanation: Non-rivalry justifies policy support for innovation and diffusion when private appropriability is limited.

questions.questionText: What does conditional convergence imply for benchmarking poorer economies against richer ones in empirical work?
options: Absolute catch-up is automatic regardless of savings, demographics, technology, or institutions.
Poorer economies should grow faster when fundamentals are similar; in practice this produces convergence clubs rather than one global steady state.
Population growth alone determines steady-state income, so demography can ensure convergence even with weak institutions.
Convergence patterns are random because identification is impossible.
questions.correctAnswer: Poorer economies should grow faster when fundamentals are similar; in practice this produces convergence clubs rather than one global steady state.
questions.explanation: The workhorse prediction is conditional, not absolute, convergence; heterogeneous fundamentals yield multiple steady states.

questions.questionText: In Sachs’s geography narrative, how can a high malaria burden generate persistent underdevelopment risks through economic channels?
options: It raises leisure and saving and therefore accelerates capital deepening.
It reduces labor productivity and schooling, raises mortality, and increases fiscal burdens, discouraging private investment and risking low-income traps unless addressed.
It has no macroeconomic effects because modern economies are service-based.
It guarantees higher trade volumes because aid inflows raise foreign exchange earnings.
questions.correctAnswer: It reduces labor productivity and schooling, raises mortality, and increases fiscal burdens, discouraging private investment and risking low-income traps unless addressed.
questions.explanation: Disease ecology interacts with fiscal capacity and private incentives; the channel is economic as well as biomedical.

questions.questionText: What is the key dynamic difference between poverty-trap models and the standard Solow model, and why does that difference matter for policy?
options: Solow features thresholds and complementarities; trap models assume linear accumulation.

Trap models include thresholds and complementarities that can block takeoff at low levels of capital or skills, while Solow predicts smooth convergence conditional on fundamentals; big-push policies may be efficient when traps exist.
The two approaches make identical predictions, so policy is unaffected by model choice.
Only trap models include technology; Solow treats technology as irrelevant to long-run growth.
questions.correctAnswer: Trap models include thresholds and complementarities that can block takeoff at low levels of capital or skills, while Solow predicts smooth convergence conditional on fundamentals; big-push policies may be efficient when traps exist.
questions.explanation: Nonlinearities justify coordinated public investment; without them, gradual accumulation suffices.

questions.questionText: Why is endogeneity a first-order concern in cross-country regressions that relate income to institutions, openness, and education, and what problem does it create for interpretation?
options: Ordinary least squares cannot estimate models with multiple regressors, so instruments are always required.

Institutions, trade, and human capital are jointly determined with income and are affected by omitted variables; without identification, coefficients confound reverse causality and unobserved heterogeneity with the causal effect of interest.
GDP is denominated in dollars; linear regression is invalid without market-rate PPP conversion.
Large macro samples bias standard errors downward regardless of the model.
questions.correctAnswer: Institutions, trade, and human capital are jointly determined with income and are affected by omitted variables; without identification, coefficients confound reverse causality and unobserved heterogeneity with the causal effect of interest.
questions.explanation: Causal interpretation requires exogenous variation via instruments, panels, or quasi-experimental designs.

questions.questionText: Why is historical settler mortality a plausible instrument for contemporary institutional quality in colonial settings?
options: It predicted whether Europeans could establish durable settlements and transplant relatively inclusive legal constraints; where mortality was high, colonizers relied on extractive arrangements that persisted.
It directly determines today’s labor productivity through current disease prevalence, so it captures the biological channel from health to income.
It perfectly measures cultural distance to Europe and therefore citizens’ preferences for redistribution today.
It is a proxy for soil fertility; fertile colonies specialized in plantations and ended up poor because agriculture crowds out industry by accounting identity.
questions.correctAnswer: It predicted whether Europeans could establish durable settlements and transplant relatively inclusive legal constraints; where mortality was high, colonizers relied on extractive arrangements that persisted.
questions.explanation: The exclusion restriction is that historical mortality shifts institutions but not current income directly once present-day health is controlled; persistence transmits institutional effects.

questions.questionText: A gravity-based instrument uses predicted bilateral trade flows to estimate the causal effect of openness on income. Which identifying assumption is required?
options: Predicted trade is orthogonal to income determinants except via actual trade after conditioning on size and distance covariates.
Predicted trade must exceed actual trade for most pairs to avoid weak instruments.
Predicted trade cannot include distance because distance affects transport productivity directly.
Predicted trade must match observed trade exactly in-sample to satisfy relevance.
questions.correctAnswer: Predicted trade is orthogonal to income determinants except via actual trade after conditioning on size and distance covariates.
questions.explanation: Relevance comes from geography; exclusion requires that geographic shifters influence income only through trade, not through other channels once controls are included.

questions.questionText: A study reports a large effect of a broad ‘institutions’ index on income. Which critique most improves the credibility of the mechanism story?
options: Decompose the index into conceptually distinct pillars and test robustness with alternative measures to mitigate measurement error and construct heterogeneity.
Drop the institutions variable; composite indices are ordinal and coefficients on ordinal scales cannot be interpreted at all.
Replace the institutions index with the corruption subcomponent only, because corruption is the true cause of underdevelopment.
Add more controls until the coefficient becomes insignificant, which proves the original estimate was spurious.
questions.correctAnswer: Decompose the index into conceptually distinct pillars and test robustness with alternative measures to mitigate measurement error and construct heterogeneity.
questions.explanation: Construct validity and attenuation bias are central; unpacking components clarifies which institutional channels matter.

questions.questionText: How can a resource boom undermine inclusive growth through a Dutch disease mechanism?
options: Boom-driven real appreciation and reallocation shrink learning-intensive tradables and weaken fiscal and institutional quality when rents are volatile.
Public revenues rise, so inequality must fall as a matter of accounting.
Real appreciation has no effect on export competitiveness because prices are sticky in the short run.
Resource windfalls always create sovereign wealth funds that perfectly smooth consumption for the poor.
questions.correctAnswer: Boom-driven real appreciation and reallocation shrink learning-intensive tradables and weaken fiscal and institutional quality when rents are volatile.
questions.explanation: The spending and resource-movement effects reduce tradables; weak institutions can turn volatility into persistence through procyclical policy.

questions.questionText: During a terms-of-trade bust in a small commodity exporter, which macro package best preserves stability while limiting scarring?
options: Let the currency depreciate to support rebalancing, activate countercyclical fiscal buffers, and target temporary support to exposed workers and regions.
Fix the exchange rate and cut social spending across the board to signal toughness.
Finance the entire deficit with short-term foreign debt to avoid domestic adjustment.
Ban imports in the affected sectors to protect employment until prices recover.
questions.correctAnswer: Let the currency depreciate to support rebalancing, activate countercyclical fiscal buffers, and target temporary support to exposed workers and regions.
questions.explanation: Relative-price adjustment plus prebuilt buffers and targeted insurance protect the floor without triggering debt spirals.

questions.questionText: Informal employment provides livelihoods for many workers. Why can high informality still impede inclusive growth?
options: Informality constrains scale, contracts, and credit, depresses productivity growth, and narrows the tax base needed for public goods and social insurance.
Informality always pays higher wages, which draws too many skilled workers out of formal firms.
Informality eliminates corruption and therefore reduces inequality by itself.
Informality ensures tax neutrality, so it cannot distort investment or productivity.
questions.correctAnswer: Informality constrains scale, contracts, and credit, depresses productivity growth, and narrows the tax base needed for public goods and social insurance.
questions.explanation: Low-productivity traps and weak state capacity interact; formalization complements capability building and revenue mobilization.

questions.questionText: What is the central policy insight from structural transformation for low-income economies?
options: Raising farm productivity typically accelerates, rather than slows, labor reallocation by freeing workers and raising demand for non-farm goods.
Services cannot contribute to productivity growth because they are non-tradable by definition.
Manufacturing shares must rise permanently for growth to continue.
Urbanization is largely cosmetic and has little connection to productivity.
questions.correctAnswer: Raising farm productivity typically accelerates, rather than slows, labor reallocation by freeing workers and raising demand for non-farm goods.
questions.explanation: Agricultural gains and non-farm expansion are complements through both supply (released labor) and demand (income effects).

questions.questionText: How did successful East Asian industrial policies reconcile selectivity with global competition?
options: They coupled targeted support with export discipline and performance-based sunset clauses, forcing firms to upgrade while remaining exposed to international rivalry.
They insulated incumbents behind permanent high tariffs until they achieved global scale.
They banned technology licensing so domestic firms learned only by doing.
They relied exclusively on tax holidays without monitoring or withdrawal.
questions.correctAnswer: They coupled targeted support with export discipline and performance-based sunset clauses, forcing firms to upgrade while remaining exposed to international rivalry.
questions.explanation: Discipline plus support mitigates rent-seeking and aligns assistance with capability accumulation.

questions.questionText: Why can place-based transition policies be more compatible with openness than broad tariffs?
options: They compensate communities and workers for concentrated losses without granting protection rents to specific firms, keeping competition intact.
They are cheaper than any tariff by identity.
They guarantee new factories will locate in declining regions within one electoral cycle.
They remove the need for national safety nets entirely.
questions.correctAnswer: They compensate communities and workers for concentrated losses without granting protection rents to specific firms, keeping competition intact.
questions.explanation: Designing compensation for people rather than sectors avoids entrenching inefficient structures.

questions.questionText: Creative destruction raises productivity. What additional step preserves legitimacy for that process in unequal regions?
options: Pair innovation with credible insurance and active transition support to avoid persistent local scarring.
Limit entry to protect incumbent employers from turbulence.
Ban automation until displaced workers retire.
Rely on unconditional cash transfers only; retraining is rarely effective.
questions.correctAnswer: Pair innovation with credible insurance and active transition support to avoid persistent local scarring.
questions.explanation: Adjustment policy helps maintain a coalition for efficiency-enhancing reallocation.

questions.questionText: A government considers a large nationwide minimum wage hike. What is the most defensible concern at a master’s level?
options: In thin local labor markets with monopsony power, moderate increases can raise employment, but abrupt large hikes risk disemployment; pairing wage policy with earned-income credits and mobility support hedges this risk.
Minimum wages always increase unemployment regardless of context.
If average productivity is rising, the wage floor is irrelevant to distributional outcomes.
Minimum wages are unnecessary because informal markets clear wages efficiently.
questions.correctAnswer: In thin local labor markets with monopsony power, moderate increases can raise employment, but abrupt large hikes risk disemployment; pairing wage policy with earned-income credits and mobility support hedges this risk.
questions.explanation: Market structure and adjustment capacity determine elasticities; complementary tools share the load between firms and the fisc.

questions.questionText: Which poverty measure captures the intensity of shortfalls among the poor rather than just the incidence?
options: Headcount ratio at the poverty line.
Poverty gap index that averages proportional shortfalls below the line.
Top 1 percent income share.
Gini coefficient.
questions.correctAnswer: Poverty gap index that averages proportional shortfalls below the line.
questions.explanation: The headcount ignores how far below the line people are; the gap incorporates depth.

questions.questionText: Why do purchasing power parity (PPP) conversions meaningfully change global poverty counts relative to market exchange rates?
options: PPP reflects the relative price of non-tradables in local consumption bundles; differences there can shift many households across absolute lines.
PPP raises all prices uniformly, so it should not matter for counts in practice.
PPP applies only to capital goods and therefore overstates poverty mechanically.
PPP equals the market rate in low-inflation countries, so trends are identical.
questions.correctAnswer: PPP reflects the relative price of non-tradables in local consumption bundles; differences there can shift many households across absolute lines.
questions.explanation: Absolute poverty is about real consumption possibilities, not nominal foreign currency purchasing power.

questions.questionText: What does the Human Capital Index (HCI) try to measure, and why is it macroeconomically relevant?
options: It estimates the productivity a child born today can achieve by age 18 given current health and education; this proxies the future efficiency of labor and potential output.
It measures the government’s education spending share and thus debt sustainability.
It records tertiary enrollment and therefore total factor productivity by identity.
It is a composite of teacher salaries that predicts inflation persistence.
questions.correctAnswer: It estimates the productivity a child born today can achieve by age 18 given current health and education; this proxies the future efficiency of labor and potential output.
questions.explanation: HCI links today’s capability investments to tomorrow’s effective labor and growth.

questions.questionText: What policy mix best supports inclusive outcomes during rapid automation?
options: Encourage adoption while providing portable benefits, wage insurance, and targeted upskilling into expanding sectors so productivity gains diffuse without persistent displacement.
Ban labor-saving technologies until unemployment returns to its natural rate.
Subsidize incumbents to keep existing jobs regardless of technology choice.
Replace active labor market policy with a universal basic income only.
questions.correctAnswer: Encourage adoption while providing portable benefits, wage insurance, and targeted upskilling into expanding sectors so productivity gains diffuse without persistent displacement.
questions.explanation: Pairing innovation with risk-sharing and mobility preserves both efficiency and legitimacy.

questions.questionText: In high land-inequality settings, which mechanism makes land reform potentially growth-enhancing rather than purely redistributive?
options: Relaxed collateral constraints for smallholders raise investment in land-augmenting inputs and aggregate productivity, especially when paired with extension and market access.
Fragmentation automatically raises yields because small is always efficient.
Reform reduces rural–urban migration and therefore raises urban wages by supply effects alone.
Land titling changes only who gets rents and does not influence credit or effort.
questions.correctAnswer: Relaxed collateral constraints for smallholders raise investment in land-augmenting inputs and aggregate productivity, especially when paired with extension and market access.
questions.explanation: Credit access and security shape input choices; complementary services determine productivity effects.

questions.questionText: How can high inequality weaken institutional quality through political economy channels?
options: Concentrated wealth enables incumbents to block entry and new technologies that threaten rents, sustaining extractive rules and dampening innovation.
High inequality reduces elite rents, so elites diversify by investing in public goods.
Inequality has no implication for institutions once elections are held regularly.
Inequality mechanically forces stronger rule of law because wealth requires courts.
questions.correctAnswer: Concentrated wealth enables incumbents to block entry and new technologies that threaten rents, sustaining extractive rules and dampening innovation.
questions.explanation: Elite capture links distribution to institutional stagnation and innovation suppression.

questions.questionText: Which reform bundle most increases the poverty-reducing effect of a given growth rate in a highly unequal economy?
options: Targeted expansion of quality basic services, reduced spatial frictions to jobs, and improved credit for viable small firms with clear sunset rules.
Broad fuel subsidies and untargeted investment tax credits.
Comprehensive import protection for low-skill industries to halt reallocation.
Across-the-board corporate tax cuts with no conditionality.
questions.correctAnswer: Targeted expansion of quality basic services, reduced spatial frictions to jobs, and improved credit for viable small firms with clear sunset rules.
questions.explanation: Opportunity expansion and mobility raise the elasticity of poverty reduction with respect to growth.

questions.questionText: What is a balanced way to think about emigration and inclusive growth in sending countries?
options: Remittances and network effects can finance human capital and entrepreneurship, but large skilled outflows risk brain drain; policies for training, credential recognition, and diaspora links can tilt outcomes toward brain circulation.
Emigration always reduces welfare because it lowers population.
Restricting emigration guarantees faster domestic skill formation.
Emigration is distributionally neutral because it affects only wages, not opportunities.
questions.correctAnswer: Remittances and network effects can finance human capital and entrepreneurship, but large skilled outflows risk brain drain; policies for training, credential recognition, and diaspora links can tilt outcomes toward brain circulation.
questions.explanation: Net effects depend on composition and policy; institutions can shape circulation rather than one-way loss.

questions.questionText: Which evaluation strategy best identifies the causal employment effect of a place-based program?
options: Difference-in-differences with well-matched controls, verified parallel pre-trends, and checks for spillovers to neighboring areas.
Before–after comparisons in treated areas only.
Cross-sectional regressions of job growth on subsidy size without fixed effects.
Comparing national employment before and after the program start date.
questions.correctAnswer: Difference-in-differences with well-matched controls, verified parallel pre-trends, and checks for spillovers to neighboring areas.
questions.explanation: Credible counterfactuals and stable pre-trends are central; spillovers can bias estimates toward zero or away from it.

questions.questionText: Why is corruption especially harmful for inclusive growth when it erodes tax capacity?
options: Weak revenue undermines public goods, risk-sharing, and policy credibility, discouraging private investment and narrowing opportunity.
Bribes transfer money to the poor, which directly reduces inequality.
Tax capacity is unrelated to growth because private finance can substitute fully.
Corruption neutralizes informality by equalizing firms’ effective tax rates.
questions.correctAnswer: Weak revenue undermines public goods, risk-sharing, and policy credibility, discouraging private investment and narrowing opportunity.
questions.explanation: Fiscal capacity is an input into production through credible service delivery and stabilization.

questions.questionText: Through which realistic channel can financial development support inclusive growth without heightening fragility?
options: Improved intermediation relaxes credit constraints for capable households and small firms while macroprudential rules lean against leverage cycles.
Expanding derivatives trading automatically lowers poverty by increasing liquidity.
Private credit-to-GDP can rise indefinitely with no crisis risk in modern systems.
Full capital-account liberalization equalizes borrowing costs for all agents.
questions.correctAnswer: Improved intermediation relaxes credit constraints for capable households and small firms while macroprudential rules lean against leverage cycles.
questions.explanation: Access and prudence must move together; otherwise leverage amplifies downturns that hit vulnerable borrowers hardest.

questions.questionText: How does urban planning shape both productivity and inclusion in fast-growing cities?
options: Dense, mixed-use zoning and mass transit that reduce commute times raise agglomeration benefits and expand access to jobs for low-income workers.
Height limits universally raise productivity by preserving heritage districts.
Zoning is irrelevant for firm productivity because firms instantly adjust locations.
Informal settlements vanish automatically as income rises, so planning is unnecessary.
questions.correctAnswer: Dense, mixed-use zoning and mass transit that reduce commute times raise agglomeration benefits and expand access to jobs for low-income workers.
questions.explanation: Connectivity and affordability determine whether agglomeration economies are realized and shared.

questions.questionText: What is the most defensible interpretation of the Kuznets curve for contemporary policy design?
options: It is a conditional hypothesis: early structural change can raise inequality; later democratization, education expansion, and policy can reverse it, but outcomes depend on institutions.
It is a law of nature; inequality must fall automatically with growth once a threshold is crossed.
It proves redistribution is unnecessary in all contexts.
It implies late industrializers cannot reduce inequality without first shrinking.
questions.correctAnswer: It is a conditional hypothesis: early structural change can raise inequality; later democratization, education expansion, and policy can reverse it, but outcomes depend on institutions.
questions.explanation: The curve is not fate; institutions and policies shape the trajectory.

questions.questionText: A cash transfer raised school attendance but test scores did not improve over two years. What is the most appropriate policy reading?
options: Attendance is a necessary input; complementary investments in pedagogy, teacher quality, and measurement are required to translate participation into learning and later productivity.
The program failed and should be canceled because learning did not rise immediately.
Transfers distort labor supply and therefore lower national productivity.
Learning is irrelevant for growth given that attendance improved.
questions.correctAnswer: Attendance is a necessary input; complementary investments in pedagogy, teacher quality, and measurement are required to translate participation into learning and later productivity.
questions.explanation: Inputs must be paired with quality to affect human capital; short horizons may miss learning gains unless teaching improves.

questions.questionText: What is the most policy-relevant distinction between absolute and relative poverty when interpreting progress over a decade?
options: Absolute poverty uses a fixed real standard of basic needs, while relative poverty benchmarks individuals against the contemporary distribution within a society.
Absolute poverty is measured in foreign currency, whereas relative poverty is measured in local currency.
Absolute poverty focuses on consumption and relative poverty on income; the two never overlap.
Absolute poverty rises mechanically with inflation, while relative poverty is invariant to prices.
questions.correctAnswer: Absolute poverty uses a fixed real standard of basic needs, while relative poverty benchmarks individuals against the contemporary distribution within a society.
questions.explanation: Absolute lines assess command over essentials; relative lines track social inclusion thresholds as the distribution evolves.

questions.questionText: Why do broad fuel subsidies typically undermine inclusive growth even when they stabilize prices in the short run?
options: They are often regressive because higher-income households consume more energy, they are fiscally costly, and they distort investment toward energy-intensive activities that slow the transition.
They automatically raise labor productivity by lowering firms’ energy bills in all sectors.
They can be fully financed by carbon credits, so they do not crowd out social spending.
They mainly benefit rural poor who spend a larger budget share on gasoline than the rich.
questions.correctAnswer: They are often regressive because higher-income households consume more energy, they are fiscally costly, and they distort investment toward energy-intensive activities that slow the transition.
questions.explanation: Untargeted price controls leak benefits up the income ladder and absorb fiscal space needed for targeted insurance.

questions.questionText: In a small open economy with credible inflation targeting and flexible exchange rates, which mechanism typically cushions an external demand slump?
options: Exchange-rate depreciation improves net exports while monetary policy eases to stabilize domestic demand.
Across-the-board wage freezes prevent pass-through to prices and thus raise real wages.
Large import bans protect domestic producers with minimal efficiency costs.
A permanent balanced-budget rule eliminates the need for countercyclical policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Exchange-rate depreciation improves net exports while monetary policy eases to stabilize domestic demand.
questions.explanation: A floating rate acts as an external buffer; the policy rate anchors nominal expectations.

questions.questionText: What makes exchange-rate pass-through particularly relevant for inflation and equity in emerging markets?
options: Depreciations can transmit quickly to tradable prices; low-income households devoted to food and fuel consumption may face sharper real-income hits unless buffered.
Depreciations are irrelevant for prices when central banks target inflation.
Pass-through is identical across all product categories and income groups.
Appreciations raise inflation more than depreciations because of menu costs.
questions.correctAnswer: Depreciations can transmit quickly to tradable prices; low-income households devoted to food and fuel consumption may face sharper real-income hits unless buffered.
questions.explanation: Heterogeneous baskets matter for distribution; targeted measures can cushion vulnerable groups.

questions.questionText: Which macroprudential set most directly leans against credit booms that amplify inequality during busts?
options: Countercyclical capital buffers, loan-to-value and debt-to-income limits, and dynamic provisioning tied to credit growth.
Price controls on food and fuel, plus export taxes on commodities.
Nominal wage guidelines and hiring subsidies for export sectors.
Tariff surcharges and local-content rules for consumer durables.
questions.correctAnswer: Countercyclical capital buffers, loan-to-value and debt-to-income limits, and dynamic provisioning tied to credit growth.
questions.explanation: These tools target leverage externalities and borrower resilience rather than masking risks with protectionism.

questions.questionText: Why might a universal basic income be dominated by targeted social insurance within the course’s framework?
options: Targeted insurance concentrates scarce fiscal resources on exposed risks and can be paired with services that build opportunity, while a universal transfer may dilute funds and crowd out capability investments.
Universal transfers always cause inflation that offsets any gains for the poor.
Targeting eliminates all administrative costs and errors of exclusion.
Universal approaches cannot coexist with contributory programs by definition.
questions.correctAnswer: Targeted insurance concentrates scarce fiscal resources on exposed risks and can be paired with services that build opportunity, while a universal transfer may dilute funds and crowd out capability investments.
questions.explanation: Insurance design should reflect budget constraints, heterogeneous risks, and the need for complementary services.

questions.questionText: Which limitation of randomized controlled trials is most salient when moving from pilot to nationwide policy?
options: External validity can be limited because effects depend on context, implementation capacity, and general-equilibrium feedbacks that differ at scale.
RCTs cannot estimate any average treatment effect without structural models.
They cannot measure outcomes beyond income or consumption.
Ethical review boards always prohibit randomization, so results rarely generalize.
questions.correctAnswer: External validity can be limited because effects depend on context, implementation capacity, and general-equilibrium feedbacks that differ at scale.
questions.explanation: Scaling changes constraints, selection, spillovers, and political economy; careful piloting plus theory enhances transportability.

questions.questionText: What is the clearest diagnostic of a weak counterfactual in a difference-in-differences study?
options: Treatment and control units show divergent pre-treatment trends that violate the parallel-trends assumption.
The standard errors are clustered at the unit level.
The control group is larger than the treated group.
Covariates are balanced at baseline after weighting.
questions.correctAnswer: Treatment and control units show divergent pre-treatment trends that violate the parallel-trends assumption.
questions.explanation: Parallel trends underpins identification; visual and statistical checks are essential.

questions.questionText: In a sharp regression-discontinuity design, which threat most directly undermines causal interpretation?
options: Precise manipulation of the running variable near the cutoff so units self-select into treatment.
Having too many observations around the cutoff compared with the rest of the sample.
Including high-order polynomials in the specification.
Using a bandwidth that is symmetric around the cutoff.
questions.correctAnswer: Precise manipulation of the running variable near the cutoff so units self-select into treatment.
questions.explanation: Sorting at the threshold breaks local randomization; density tests and institutional knowledge help detect it.

questions.questionText: In staggered-adoption policy settings, why can a naive two-way fixed effects DiD misstate average treatment effects?
options: With heterogeneous treatment effects over time, the estimator can put negative weights on some comparisons, biasing the aggregate.
Two-way fixed effects always overfit the data and inflate R-squared.
The approach cannot include unit and time fixed effects simultaneously.
It requires perfectly balanced panels; otherwise it is undefined.
questions.correctAnswer: With heterogeneous treatment effects over time, the estimator can put negative weights on some comparisons, biasing the aggregate.
questions.explanation: Modern estimators (e.g., event-study decompositions or interaction-weighted DiD) avoid problematic weighting in staggered designs.

questions.questionText: What is the main advantage of synthetic control for evaluating a single treated region’s policy reform?
options: It constructs a data-driven counterfactual from a convex combination of donors that matches pre-treatment trajectories, improving credibility when few controls exist.
It eliminates the need for pre-treatment data by optimizing on post-treatment fit.
It guarantees causal identification even if treatment is anticipated.
It produces unbiased standard errors without inference procedures.
questions.correctAnswer: It constructs a data-driven counterfactual from a convex combination of donors that matches pre-treatment trajectories, improving credibility when few controls exist.
questions.explanation: Good pre-treatment fit strengthens the case that post-treatment divergence reflects causal effects; inference typically uses placebo tests.

questions.questionText: Why do multiple-hypothesis tests and data mining pose risks for evidence-based policy claims?
options: They inflate false positives unless adjustments or pre-analysis plans control the family-wise error or false discovery rate.
They only reduce statistical power, which is harmless for inference.
They primarily bias standard errors upward, making results conservative.
They are a concern only in laboratory experiments, not in field data.
questions.correctAnswer: They inflate false positives unless adjustments or pre-analysis plans control the family-wise error or false discovery rate.
questions.explanation: Transparent ex ante plans and correction methods discipline inference when testing many outcomes or subgroups.

questions.questionText: Which decomposition helps distinguish between structural and compositional sources of inequality change over time?
options: Between-group and within-group components using Theil or variance decompositions.
The Gini coefficient alone, because it isolates group effects.
Only top income shares, since they capture the entire distribution.
Lorenz dominance, which is unrelated to decomposition.
questions.correctAnswer: Between-group and within-group components using Theil or variance decompositions.
questions.explanation: Additive decompositions reveal whether dispersion arises from group gaps or dispersion within groups.

questions.questionText: What does a growth incidence curve reveal that average growth rates can hide?
options: It shows how growth rates differ across the entire income distribution, identifying who gains or loses relative to the mean.
It eliminates the need for poverty and inequality measures.
It indicates the rate of technological progress separately from factor accumulation.
It proves whether social welfare has risen irrespective of preferences.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows how growth rates differ across the entire income distribution, identifying who gains or loses relative to the mean.
questions.explanation: Distribution-sensitive diagnostics help evaluate inclusiveness of growth beyond aggregates.

questions.questionText: Why is Lorenz dominance a strong basis for comparing inequality across countries?
options: If one income distribution Lorenz-dominates another, all inequality-averse social welfare functions agree on lower inequality.
Lorenz dominance uses only the Gini coefficient, which is sufficient for all rankings.
It compares mean incomes directly and therefore controls for poverty.
It holds for any two distributions as long as they have the same variance.
questions.correctAnswer: If one income distribution Lorenz-dominates another, all inequality-averse social welfare functions agree on lower inequality.
questions.explanation: Lorenz dominance is preference-robust for a wide class of welfare functions.

questions.questionText: What is the primary policy rationale for carbon border adjustment mechanisms (CBAMs) in an inclusive green growth strategy?
options: They reduce leakage by aligning the carbon cost on imports with domestic carbon pricing, while generating revenue that can finance domestic transition support.
They guarantee energy independence by banning fossil-fuel imports.
They ensure all trading partners adopt identical carbon taxes immediately.
They replace the need for any domestic decarbonization policies.
questions.correctAnswer: They reduce leakage by aligning the carbon cost on imports with domestic carbon pricing, while generating revenue that can finance domestic transition support.
questions.explanation: Border adjustments preserve incentives for clean production and provide fiscal space to cushion affected households and regions.

questions.questionText: Under what conditions can green industrial policy complement carbon pricing rather than substitute for it?
options: When learning-by-doing and network externalities create dynamic spillovers and coordination failures that pure pricing may not fully unlock, provided support is time-bound and performance-based.
When domestic content rules guarantee local jobs regardless of costs or spillovers.
When technology has no scale economies and mature supply chains already exist.
When the goal is to stabilize retail energy prices permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: When learning-by-doing and network externalities create dynamic spillovers and coordination failures that pure pricing may not fully unlock, provided support is time-bound and performance-based.
questions.explanation: Targeted, disciplined support can accelerate diffusion where private appropriability is limited.

questions.questionText: Which feature most increases the credibility of a public investment project appraisal in a constrained state?
options: A transparent pipeline governed by standardized cost-benefit analysis with shadow pricing and ex post audits linked to a public asset registry.
An emphasis on ribbon-cutting timelines and employment multipliers only.
Exclusive reliance on donor feasibility studies without local review.
Delegating approval to a single line ministry to speed up execution.
questions.correctAnswer: A transparent pipeline governed by standardized cost-benefit analysis with shadow pricing and ex post audits linked to a public asset registry.
questions.explanation: Project governance and feedback loops raise the productivity of scarce fiscal space.

questions.questionText: Why can weak competition policy undermine inclusive growth in concentrated domestic markets?
options: Market power can suppress wage growth, raise consumer prices, and depress diffusion of new technologies; robust antitrust and contestable entry conditions support both efficiency and distribution.
Concentration always raises investment and therefore stimulates inclusive growth.
Monopoly pricing benefits low-income households because it stabilizes supply.
Competition policy affects only export markets and not domestic inclusion.
questions.correctAnswer: Market power can suppress wage growth, raise consumer prices, and depress diffusion of new technologies; robust antitrust and contestable entry conditions support both efficiency and distribution.
questions.explanation: Dynamic efficiency and fairness are served by entry, diffusion, and worker bargaining power.

questions.questionText: What does the government debt sustainability condition r − g > 0 or < 0 imply for inclusive fiscal policy design?
options: When the interest rate exceeds the growth rate, primary surpluses are needed to stabilize debt; countercyclical buffers and high-multiplier, well-governed investment become crucial.
If growth exceeds the interest rate, debt dynamics are irrelevant and any level of transfers is sustainable.
If the interest rate is below growth, raising taxes to run surpluses always maximizes welfare.
Debt dynamics depend only on the current account, not on primary balances.
questions.correctAnswer: When the interest rate exceeds the growth rate, primary surpluses are needed to stabilize debt; countercyclical buffers and high-multiplier, well-governed investment become crucial.
questions.explanation: The intertemporal constraint ties distributional ambitions to credible financing and growth-enhancing uses of debt.

questions.questionText: Which channel most plausibly connects digital public infrastructure to inclusive growth?
options: Interoperable digital ID, payments, and data-sharing rails lower transaction costs and verification frictions, expanding access to finance and public services for excluded households and firms.
Digital systems mainly reduce inequality by automating all public services.
Digital IDs guarantee privacy and thus have no bearing on inclusion.
Digital rails always eliminate the need for regulation and competition policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Interoperable digital ID, payments, and data-sharing rails lower transaction costs and verification frictions, expanding access to finance and public services for excluded households and firms.
questions.explanation: Foundational rails are public goods that crowd in private innovation and lower barriers for the excluded.

questions.questionText: What is the main economic rationale for active labor market policies (ALMPs) in a just transition context?
options: They reduce matching frictions and skill mismatch during sectoral reallocation, raising reemployment probabilities and earnings for displaced workers.
They permanently substitute for wage growth, so firms can hold wages flat.
They eliminate regional disparities by relocating firms rather than workers.
They ensure automation has no effect on employment levels.
questions.correctAnswer: They reduce matching frictions and skill mismatch during sectoral reallocation, raising reemployment probabilities and earnings for displaced workers.
questions.explanation: Targeted training, job-search assistance, and wage insurance help workers move toward expanding sectors.

questions.questionText: Which argument best justifies combining carbon pricing with lump-sum dividends to households?
options: Dividends recycle revenue transparently, offsetting average household losses and preserving political support while maintaining the marginal abatement incentive.
Dividends eliminate the need for any complementary industrial policy.
Dividends shift the tax entirely to firms, so consumers face no incentives.
Dividends ensure emissions fall even if the carbon price is set near zero.
questions.correctAnswer: Dividends recycle revenue transparently, offsetting average household losses and preserving political support while maintaining the marginal abatement incentive.
questions.explanation: Revenue neutrality for households can build durable coalitions without blunting the price signal.

questions.questionText: Why can weak public procurement and SOE governance be particularly costly for inclusive growth?
options: They raise unit costs and delay service delivery, diverting fiscal space from high-multiplier programs and eroding trust needed to sustain redistribution and investment.
They affect only capital-intensive projects and have no bearing on social policy.
They mainly increase private investment by creating more market opportunities.
They ensure universal service obligations are always met at the lowest cost.
questions.correctAnswer: They raise unit costs and delay service delivery, diverting fiscal space from high-multiplier programs and eroding trust needed to sustain redistribution and investment.
questions.explanation: Procurement and SOE governance determine the productivity of public spending—the engine for inclusive services and infrastructure.

questions.questionText: A ministry must choose between expanding access (seats) and improving quality (pedagogy) in basic education under a tight budget. What principle from the course offers the most defensible guidance?
options: Sequencing should target the binding constraint: if enrollment is low due to price or distance, expand access; if enrollment is high but learning is weak, prioritize teacher effectiveness and pedagogy—ideally combining both when marginal returns justify it.
Always expand seats first; quality improvements can wait without cost.
Always focus on teacher salaries; enrollment will adjust automatically.
Prioritize tertiary education because spillovers are larger at the top of the pyramid.
questions.correctAnswer: Sequencing should target the binding constraint: if enrollment is low due to price or distance, expand access; if enrollment is high but learning is weak, prioritize teacher effectiveness and pedagogy—ideally combining both when marginal returns justify it.
questions.explanation: An inclusion lens asks where the marginal unit of spending yields the largest learning and opportunity gains, given current gaps.

questions.questionText: In lower-income economies seeking revenue without choking investment, which tax design best balances efficiency with equity and administrability?
options: Rely primarily on trade tariffs because they are easy to collect and progressive.
Adopt a broad-base value-added tax with few exemptions, complemented by targeted cash transfers to protect low-income households.
Shift to corporate income taxation only, since firms can bear the burden without pass-through.
Replace indirect taxes with a uniform head tax to avoid distortions.
questions.correctAnswer: Adopt a broad-base value-added tax with few exemptions, complemented by targeted cash transfers to protect low-income households.
questions.explanation: A clean VAT raises substantial revenue with limited production distortions; distributional concerns are better handled on the spending side.

questions.questionText: When is in-kind support (for example food staples or energy vouchers) more defensible than cash transfers in an inclusive growth strategy?
options: When local markets function well and prices are stable.
When there are large consumption externalities, thin or failing markets, or short-run supply shocks that make cash leak into higher prices.
When the government wants to signal toughness on inflation regardless of welfare.
Whenever administrative capacity is low, since in-kind is always easier.
questions.correctAnswer: When there are large consumption externalities, thin or failing markets, or short-run supply shocks that make cash leak into higher prices.
questions.explanation: In-kind can target externalities and stabilize quantities when markets cannot; otherwise cash preserves choice and efficiency.

questions.questionText: For a small commodity exporter facing volatile terms of trade, which monetary–exchange-rate arrangement best cushions shocks while keeping expectations anchored?
options: A hard peg to the dollar with no independent monetary policy.
Fully free float with no nominal anchor or intervention framework.
Flexible exchange rate with credible inflation targeting and FX interventions limited to disorderly market conditions.
A crawling peg set monthly by a fiscal council.
questions.correctAnswer: Flexible exchange rate with credible inflation targeting and FX interventions limited to disorderly market conditions.
questions.explanation: A float allows relative prices to adjust; an inflation target anchors nominal expectations; limited FX operations stabilize markets without targeting levels.

questions.questionText: During a sudden stop in capital inflows, which policy mix most plausibly stabilizes the economy without amplifying inequality?
options: Use reserves and liquidity lines, allow some depreciation, tighten macroprudential constraints on FX borrowing, and target support to solvent but illiquid firms and vulnerable households.
Impose universal price controls and freeze bank deposits indefinitely.
Raise import tariffs to restore the current account and subsidize large conglomerates.
Defend the exchange rate at all costs by hiking rates until unemployment rises sharply.
questions.correctAnswer: Use reserves and liquidity lines, allow some depreciation, tighten macroprudential constraints on FX borrowing, and target support to solvent but illiquid firms and vulnerable households.
questions.explanation: Liquidity tools and relative-price adjustment limit output losses; targeted insurance reduces scarring among constrained agents.

questions.questionText: When should a sovereign consider pre-emptive debt reprofiling rather than additional austerity to restore sustainability?
options: When r − g is clearly negative and market access is abundant.
When primary surpluses consistent with social and political feasibility are insufficient to stabilize debt under realistic growth and interest rate scenarios.
Only after default has already occurred and all domestic banks are insolvent.
Whenever investors demand higher yields than peer countries, regardless of fundamentals.
questions.correctAnswer: When primary surpluses consistent with social and political feasibility are insufficient to stabilize debt under realistic growth and interest rate scenarios.
questions.explanation: A feasibility-consistent DSA can justify reprofiling to avoid excessive contraction that undermines growth and inclusion.

questions.questionText: What policy bundle best supports upgrading in global value chains beyond simple assembly?
options: Strict local-content rules and export bans on raw materials.
Supplier development programs, standards and certification support, skills upgrading, efficient logistics, and open services trade to import know-how.
Across-the-board tax holidays with no performance conditions.
Permanent tariff protection against imported intermediates.
questions.correctAnswer: Supplier development programs, standards and certification support, skills upgrading, efficient logistics, and open services trade to import know-how.
questions.explanation: Capabilities, standards, and connectivity drive movement to higher value-added tasks; blunt protection can backfire.

questions.questionText: In network industries with large fixed costs (for example telecoms or rail), which regulatory approach best balances investment incentives with consumer welfare?
options: Rate-of-return regulation with guaranteed cost recovery and no efficiency incentives.
Price-cap or revenue-cap regulation with transparent access rules and periodic resets based on costs and quality.
Unregulated monopoly because duplication of infrastructure is wasteful.
Permanent state ownership without performance contracts.
questions.correctAnswer: Price-cap or revenue-cap regulation with transparent access rules and periodic resets based on costs and quality.
questions.explanation: Incentive regulation encourages efficiency while allowing recovery of efficient investment costs; access rules preserve competition on services.

questions.questionText: Which reform set most directly improves electricity sector reliability and fiscal sustainability?
options: Freeze tariffs to protect consumers and finance utilities through the budget.
Cost-reflective tariffs with targeted lifeline rates, loss-reduction and governance reforms, credible contracting for generation, and competitive procurement.
Privatize all assets immediately without regulatory preparation.
Mandate coal purchases at fixed prices to reduce volatility.
questions.correctAnswer: Cost-reflective tariffs with targeted lifeline rates, loss-reduction and governance reforms, credible contracting for generation, and competitive procurement.
questions.explanation: Align prices with costs, protect the poor with targeted support, and fix governance to crowd in investment and reduce quasi-fiscal deficits.

questions.questionText: For water and sanitation, what element most strengthens the case for public investment in cost-benefit analysis?
options: High land values near treatment plants.
Large health externalities from reduced disease, especially among children, plus time savings for households.
The ability to employ more public workers per dollar spent.
The political salience of ribbon-cutting opportunities.
questions.correctAnswer: Large health externalities from reduced disease, especially among children, plus time savings for households.
questions.explanation: External benefits and time savings are often the dominant welfare gains beyond direct willingness to pay.

questions.questionText: Evidence on education reforms suggests which strategy delivers the largest learning gains at scale?
options: Raising spending uniformly on inputs regardless of pedagogy.
Structured pedagogy that aligns teaching materials, teacher support, feedback, and assessment to the learning level of students.
Increasing class sizes to promote competition among students.
Eliminating standardized assessments to reduce teaching to the test.
questions.correctAnswer: Structured pedagogy that aligns teaching materials, teacher support, feedback, and assessment to the learning level of students.
questions.explanation: Teaching at the right level with aligned systems beats input-only approaches; incentives and support must cohere.

questions.questionText: Which priority set most improves pandemic preparedness without undermining routine health services?
options: Close all borders permanently and divert most health budgets to stockpiles.
Strengthen primary care and surveillance, build flexible surge capacity, invest in data systems, and maintain trust through clear risk communication.
Rely on hospitals only; primary care is irrelevant during pandemics.
Ban private providers to centralize response.
questions.correctAnswer: Strengthen primary care and surveillance, build flexible surge capacity, invest in data systems, and maintain trust through clear risk communication.
questions.explanation: Preparedness hinges on early detection, integrated primary care, flexible capacity, and public trust.

questions.questionText: What set of reforms is most likely to narrow gender gaps in labor force participation and earnings?
options: Mandate identical wages in all occupations regardless of experience.
Remove legal barriers, expand affordable childcare, improve safety and transport, and enforce fair hiring and promotion practices.
Ban part-time work to force full-time participation.
Provide tax credits only to single earners in households.
questions.correctAnswer: Remove legal barriers, expand affordable childcare, improve safety and transport, and enforce fair hiring and promotion practices.
questions.explanation: Address constraints on time, safety, mobility, and discrimination to unlock female labor supply and productivity.

questions.questionText: Why do measures of informality based on firms and those based on workers often diverge, and why does this matter for policy?
options: Worker-based measures capture employment without social protection; firm-based measures track unregistered enterprises; policies aimed at one margin may miss the other.
Both measures are identical because firms and workers formalize together.
Firm-based measures are always larger because firms are easier to survey.
Worker-based measures are irrelevant for labor policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Worker-based measures capture employment without social protection; firm-based measures track unregistered enterprises; policies aimed at one margin may miss the other.
questions.explanation: Targeting compliance, enforcement, or benefits depends on which margin of informality is binding.

questions.questionText: How should carbon be treated in public cost-benefit analysis for infrastructure?
options: Ignore it to avoid double counting with future climate policy.
Include a shadow price for emissions (for example a social cost of carbon or the expected domestic carbon price path) and test sensitivity to discount rates and abatement costs.
Count only local air pollution benefits; global carbon damages are external.
Apply zero discounting to environmental benefits but market rates to costs.
questions.correctAnswer: Include a shadow price for emissions (for example a social cost of carbon or the expected domestic carbon price path) and test sensitivity to discount rates and abatement costs.
