questions.explanation: Shadow pricing internalizes externalities; robust appraisal requires sensitivity to SCC and discounting assumptions.

questions.questionText: What is the strongest argument for declining social discount rates in very long-horizon public projects?
options: They guarantee all projects pass appraisal.
Uncertainty about future growth and interest rates implies lower certainty-equivalent discounting over long horizons, giving appropriate weight to intergenerational benefits.
They simplify accounting by using a single-digit number.
They offset political impatience rather than reflect economics.
questions.correctAnswer: Uncertainty about future growth and interest rates implies lower certainty-equivalent discounting over long horizons, giving appropriate weight to intergenerational benefits.
questions.explanation: Stochastic discounting and intergenerational equity motivate declining schedules for very long-lived assets.

questions.questionText: Which anti-corruption design most likely raises procurement value for money without stalling delivery?
options: Mandate the lowest bid wins and prohibit any quality scoring.
Publish open data on tenders and contracts, use e-procurement with standardized documents, apply risk-based audits, and require ex post performance reporting.
Allow sole-source contracting for all purchases below a high threshold.
Rotate auditors annually but keep tenders offline to reduce cyber risks.
questions.correctAnswer: Publish open data on tenders and contracts, use e-procurement with standardized documents, apply risk-based audits, and require ex post performance reporting.
questions.explanation: Transparency, standardization, and risk-based oversight deter collusion while preserving timely delivery.

questions.questionText: When does land titling most plausibly increase investment and access to credit?
options: When tenure is already secure through social norms and formal credit markets are missing.
When baseline tenure is insecure, the registry is reliable, and financial institutions accept titles as collateral.
Always, since titles automatically raise collateral values in any context.
Only in urban centers; rural areas never benefit.
questions.correctAnswer: When baseline tenure is insecure, the registry is reliable, and financial institutions accept titles as collateral.
questions.explanation: Titles raise investment when they change enforcement and collateral constraints; context determines impact.

questions.questionText: A metropolis must choose between bus rapid transit (BRT) and urban rail. Which criterion set best guides the decision?
options: Select BRT because buses are always cheaper.
Match technology to corridor demand and city form: rail for very high, sustained peak loads and dense corridors; BRT for medium loads and scalable networks; integrate with land use and fare systems.
Choose rail to signal modernity and attract foreign investment.
Prefer BRT to avoid complex institutions regardless of ridership.
questions.correctAnswer: Match technology to corridor demand and city form: rail for very high, sustained peak loads and dense corridors; BRT for medium loads and scalable networks; integrate with land use and fare systems.
questions.explanation: Capacity, cost, and urban morphology—plus integration with zoning and fares—determine welfare gains.

questions.questionText: Which agricultural strategy most supports inclusive productivity growth?
options: Permanent input subsidies with no targeting or soil testing.
Public goods such as R&D, extension, water management, and market access, complemented by smart, time-bound input support where learning or credit constraints bind.
Export bans to ensure domestic food security.
Mandatory farm fragmentation to equalize landholding.
questions.correctAnswer: Public goods such as R&D, extension, water management, and market access, complemented by smart, time-bound input support where learning or credit constraints bind.
questions.explanation: Public goods raise broad productivity; smart subsidies can overcome adoption barriers without long-run distortions.

questions.questionText: Trade facilitation reforms often yield large gains. Which package targets the core frictions?
options: Higher tariffs to manage the volume of imports.
Modern customs with risk management, electronic single windows, streamlined border agencies, and predictable fees.
Export subsidies tied to domestic content rules.
Manual inspections for every shipment to deter evasion.
questions.correctAnswer: Modern customs with risk management, electronic single windows, streamlined border agencies, and predictable fees.
questions.explanation: Reducing time and uncertainty at the border raises competitiveness and benefits small firms disproportionately.

questions.questionText: How can data governance support both innovation and inclusion in digital markets?
options: Prohibit data sharing to protect privacy even when consented.
Mandate data portability and interoperability, protect privacy by design, and ensure pro-competitive access to key datasets on fair terms.
Allow dominant platforms exclusive rights to user data to reward investment.
Outsource all data policy to private standards bodies.
questions.correctAnswer: Mandate data portability and interoperability, protect privacy by design, and ensure pro-competitive access to key datasets on fair terms.
questions.explanation: Open, secure rails lower entry barriers and enable new services while preserving trust.

questions.questionText: What is a realistic risk when scaling active labor market programs during large reallocation shocks?
options: Displacement effects where treated workers crowd out untreated workers in the same vacancy pool, requiring targeting and employer engagement to mitigate.
ALMPs always raise aggregate employment one-for-one with participants.
General equilibrium effects are negligible because matching is frictionless.
Training is universally ineffective and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Displacement effects where treated workers crowd out untreated workers in the same vacancy pool, requiring targeting and employer engagement to mitigate.
questions.explanation: Evaluation should assess spillovers and design programs to expand effective demand for trained workers.

questions.questionText: Which statement best frames the job quality agenda within inclusive growth?
options: Quantity of jobs fully captures welfare; quality is second order.

Earnings stability, safety, social protection coverage, and prospects for advancement are integral; formalization and enforcement can raise quality without destroying viable firms when phased and well-targeted.
Raising minimum wages alone is sufficient to upgrade job quality.
Job quality is a purely subjective concept and cannot inform policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Earnings stability, safety, social protection coverage, and prospects for advancement are integral; formalization and enforcement can raise quality without destroying viable firms when phased and well-targeted.
questions.explanation: Quality dimensions matter for welfare and productivity; design avoids abrupt compliance shocks for small firms.

questions.questionText: A national carbon price will fall unevenly across regions. Which compensation design best protects political support while keeping abatement incentives?
options: Uniform industrial exemptions so no firm pays the carbon price.
Targeted household rebates, mobility and housing support for affected workers, and place-based transition investment in regions with concentrated exposure.
Freeze the carbon price whenever energy prices rise.
Permanent free allocation of permits to all emitters.
questions.correctAnswer: Targeted household rebates, mobility and housing support for affected workers, and place-based transition investment in regions with concentrated exposure.
questions.explanation: Compensate people and places, not emissions, to preserve incentives while addressing concentrated losses.

questions.questionText: You are advising on a medium-term strategy that combines growth, inclusion, and decarbonization. Which integrated package is most coherent?
options: Carbon pricing with revenue recycling to households, green industrial policy that is time-bound and performance-based, active labor market programs for displaced workers, and place-based transition support linked to measurable outcomes.
Only carbon pricing, because any complementary policy dilutes efficiency.
Industrial policy only, since markets will not respond to prices.
Universal cash transfers with no sectoral measures or pricing.
questions.correctAnswer: Carbon pricing with revenue recycling to households, green industrial policy that is time-bound and performance-based, active labor market programs for displaced workers, and place-based transition support linked to measurable outcomes.
questions.explanation: Efficiency from pricing, capability building from selective support, and insurance for workers and places together sustain a durable coalition for change.

questions.questionText: According to the open-economy policy trilemma, what is the main constraint a country faces when choosing its monetary and exchange-rate regime?
options: It can simultaneously maintain a fixed exchange rate, free capital mobility, and full monetary policy independence.
It can choose any two of the following three: a fixed exchange rate, free capital mobility, and independent monetary policy; the third must be sacrificed.
It must fix the exchange rate if it wants low inflation, regardless of capital account policies.
It must impose capital controls if it wants to target inflation.
questions.correctAnswer: It can choose any two of the following three: a fixed exchange rate, free capital mobility, and independent monetary policy; the third must be sacrificed.
questions.explanation: The trilemma (impossible trinity) implies a hard trade-off; policy credibility cannot escape the geometry.

questions.questionText: When are temporary capital-flow management measures most defensible as part of an inclusive growth strategy?
options: During surges of short-term foreign inflows that fuel FX borrowing and housing booms, when macroprudential tools alone are insufficient and measures are rules-based, targeted, and time-bound.
Whenever the exchange rate appreciates, since appreciation is always harmful for exporters.
As a permanent substitute for sound bank supervision and fiscal policy.
Only after a crisis, since pre-emptive measures cannot be justified.
questions.correctAnswer: During surges of short-term foreign inflows that fuel FX borrowing and housing booms, when macroprudential tools alone are insufficient and measures are rules-based, targeted, and time-bound.
questions.explanation: Inflow-side frictions can reduce systemic risk and distributionally costly busts when paired with orthodox macroprudential policies.

questions.questionText: Why might a ‘fear of floating’ be rational in emerging economies even under formal inflation targeting?
options: Because exchange-rate movements have negligible pass-through to domestic prices in these economies.
Because dollarized balance sheets and high pass-through can make large depreciations contractionary and regressive, prompting managed floats and FX interventions to smooth volatility.
Because central banks lack any tools to influence expectations.
Because a fixed exchange rate always delivers higher growth than a float.
questions.correctAnswer: Because dollarized balance sheets and high pass-through can make large depreciations contractionary and regressive, prompting managed floats and FX interventions to smooth volatility.
questions.explanation: Liability dollarization and CPI baskets heavy in tradables create real-side costs that justify managed flexibility.

questions.questionText: Survey-based Gini coefficients often understate inequality relative to tax-record top income shares. What is the most defensible interpretation?
options: Surveys perfectly capture all incomes; tax data are biased upward by evasion.
Nonresponse and top-coding in surveys miss the upper tail; administrative data better capture top shares but may exclude informal and non-filers. Using both sources gives a fuller picture.
Tax data are irrelevant because redistribution occurs only via cash transfers.
The discrepancy proves that inequality has been falling.
questions.correctAnswer: Nonresponse and top-coding in surveys miss the upper tail; administrative data better capture top shares but may exclude informal and non-filers. Using both sources gives a fuller picture.
questions.explanation: Complementary data sources reduce bias at both tails and improve policy targeting.

questions.questionText: When is consumption a more suitable welfare metric than income for poverty analysis?
options: When labor markets are perfectly competitive and wages equal productivity.
When households smooth temporary income shocks via savings and transfers, making current consumption a better proxy for permanent income.
When the government uses progressive taxes.
When the study focuses exclusively on firms.
questions.correctAnswer: When households smooth temporary income shocks via savings and transfers, making current consumption a better proxy for permanent income.
questions.explanation: In low-income settings with volatile incomes, consumption better reflects living standards.

questions.questionText: A large oil discovery is expected to appreciate the real exchange rate. Which policy package best preserves diversification and inclusion?
options: Front-load spending, cut non-oil taxes permanently, and abandon fiscal rules.
Adopt a fiscal anchor with a sovereign wealth fund, smooth expenditure over the price cycle, and use part of rents for productivity-enhancing public goods and targeted transition support.
Ban all imports to shelter tradables.
Fix the nominal exchange rate and subsidize energy prices for industry.
questions.correctAnswer: Adopt a fiscal anchor with a sovereign wealth fund, smooth expenditure over the price cycle, and use part of rents for productivity-enhancing public goods and targeted transition support.
questions.explanation: Saving and smoothing reduce Dutch disease; capability investments and cushioning protect inclusive employment.

questions.questionText: Which governance rule most limits rent-seeking in the allocation of resource revenues?
options: Discretionary annual allocations to favored sectors decided by a small cabinet committee.
A transparent fiscal rule with published transfers to subnational governments based on objective formulas and ex post audits.
Earmarking all revenues to a single SOE without external oversight.
No reporting because secrecy deters corruption.
questions.correctAnswer: A transparent fiscal rule with published transfers to subnational governments based on objective formulas and ex post audits.
questions.explanation: Rules, transparency, and auditability reduce discretion and political capture.

questions.questionText: What makes ‘green budgeting’ more than a label in public finance?
options: Rebranding existing projects without changing appraisal methods.
Embedding climate metrics in medium-term expenditure frameworks, using climate-adjusted cost-benefit analysis and tagging to track allocations and results.
Funding only renewable energy, regardless of returns.
Publishing an annual climate speech by the finance minister.
questions.correctAnswer: Embedding climate metrics in medium-term expenditure frameworks, using climate-adjusted cost-benefit analysis and tagging to track allocations and results.
questions.explanation: Integrating appraisal, budgeting, and reporting aligns spending with mitigation and adaptation goals.

questions.questionText: How should a planner use the social cost of carbon (SCC) in project appraisal?
options: Apply an SCC or expected carbon price path to emissions and run sensitivity tests; do not double-count if pricing is already binding.
Ignore carbon because future regulation will handle it.
Count only local air-quality benefits; global externalities are irrelevant.
Set the SCC to zero for projects with high employment multipliers.
questions.correctAnswer: Apply an SCC or expected carbon price path to emissions and run sensitivity tests; do not double-count if pricing is already binding.
questions.explanation: Shadow pricing internalizes external costs and keeps incentives consistent with economy-wide instruments.

questions.questionText: Which statement best distinguishes mitigation from adaptation in distributional terms?
options: Mitigation yields global public benefits with diffuse incidence; adaptation often delivers local, immediate benefits and can be targeted to vulnerable communities.
Mitigation benefits only high-income countries, while adaptation benefits only low-income countries.
Adaptation reduces emissions directly; mitigation reduces climate damages directly.
Both are purely local policies with no cross-border spillovers.
questions.correctAnswer: Mitigation yields global public benefits with diffuse incidence; adaptation often delivers local, immediate benefits and can be targeted to vulnerable communities.
questions.explanation: This distributional contrast shapes financing and political coalitions.

questions.questionText: How can trade agreements with labor provisions plausibly improve worker welfare without becoming disguised protectionism?
options: By conditioning market access on detailed wage schedules set by importers.
By focusing on core labor standards, transparency, and capacity-building with domestic enforcement, rather than mandating sector-specific wage levels.
By requiring foreign firms to source a fixed share of inputs domestically.
By banning imports from countries with informality above a threshold.
questions.correctAnswer: By focusing on core labor standards, transparency, and capacity-building with domestic enforcement, rather than mandating sector-specific wage levels.
questions.explanation: Process and enforcement standards can raise dignity without distorting price competition via arbitrary content rules.

questions.questionText: What is the interaction between product-market power and labor-market monopsony for inclusive growth?
options: High markups raise wages by increasing profits available for sharing.
Product-market power can amplify monopsony, suppressing wage pass-through and diffusion of innovation; competition policy and worker mobility complement each other.
Monopsony is irrelevant if the product market is competitive.
If labor is mobile, product-market power benefits all workers.
questions.correctAnswer: Product-market power can amplify monopsony, suppressing wage pass-through and diffusion of innovation; competition policy and worker mobility complement each other.
questions.explanation: Dual-market power can depress wages and slow diffusion; remedies on both margins improve inclusiveness.

questions.questionText: Which financing tool most credibly captures part of transit-induced land value gains for inclusive urban investment?
options: Across-the-board increases in sales taxes.
Land value capture via betterment levies, development charges, or tax-increment financing linked to transparent zoning and affordable-housing requirements.
One-off privatization of public land without planning reforms.
Uniform property tax holidays near stations.
questions.correctAnswer: Land value capture via betterment levies, development charges, or tax-increment financing linked to transparent zoning and affordable-housing requirements.
questions.explanation: Transit raises land values; structured capture can fund connectivity and inclusion if governance is credible.

questions.questionText: What is a first-order evaluation risk for place-based programs in spatial equilibrium?
options: Benefits may reflect displacement from nearby areas rather than net job creation, requiring designs that measure spillovers and commuting responses.
Programs never change migration flows, so impacts are always local.
Spillovers bias estimates upward only; they cannot bias downward.
Parallel trends are irrelevant in spatial settings.
questions.correctAnswer: Benefits may reflect displacement from nearby areas rather than net job creation, requiring designs that measure spillovers and commuting responses.
questions.explanation: Mobility and general equilibrium can reallocate activity rather than expand it; evaluation must capture this.

questions.questionText: Which agricultural policy bundle most supports structural transformation without long-run distortions?
options: Permanent, untargeted fertilizer subsidies.
Investments in R&D and extension, improved rural roads and storage, competitive input markets, and time-bound support where learning externalities are strong.
Export bans on staple crops during normal years.
Price floors set above world prices for all crops.
questions.correctAnswer: Investments in R&D and extension, improved rural roads and storage, competitive input markets, and time-bound support where learning externalities are strong.
questions.explanation: Public goods and smart, temporary support raise productivity and facilitate reallocation.

questions.questionText: Which instrument is generally superior for easing SME credit frictions under tight budgets?
options: Interest-rate subsidies with no screening.
Partial, risk-priced credit guarantees with sunset clauses and data sharing to improve screening and crowd-in private lending.
Directed lending quotas for state banks regardless of solvency.
FX-denominated loans to reduce borrowing costs.
questions.correctAnswer: Partial, risk-priced credit guarantees with sunset clauses and data sharing to improve screening and crowd-in private lending.
questions.explanation: Guarantees target information and collateral frictions with less fiscal leakage than broad subsidies.

questions.questionText: What did rigorous evaluations of classic microfinance expansions generally find for average households?
options: Large, universal income gains within the first year.
Modest average effects with meaningful heterogeneity: some entrepreneurs expand, many households show limited changes in consumption or profits in the short run.
Significant declines in poverty across all treated communities.
No measurable effects in any subgroup.
questions.correctAnswer: Modest average effects with meaningful heterogeneity: some entrepreneurs expand, many households show limited changes in consumption or profits in the short run.
questions.explanation: Credit can be valuable for subsets with profitable opportunities; average impacts are often small near term.

questions.questionText: Parametric micro-insurance for climate risks faces ‘basis risk’. What is the inclusion concern?
options: Payouts depend on verified household losses only, which delays compensation.
Trigger indices may not correlate with individual losses, so vulnerable households can suffer uninsured shocks; product design and social backup are needed.
Premiums cannot be subsidized under any framework.
Basis risk affects only large firms, not smallholders.
questions.correctAnswer: Trigger indices may not correlate with individual losses, so vulnerable households can suffer uninsured shocks; product design and social backup are needed.
questions.explanation: Index design, layering with public relief, and clear communication mitigate basis risk.

questions.questionText: Incomplete markets models predict excess sensitivity of consumption to income. Why does this matter for inclusive stabilization policy?
options: Because if markets are incomplete, fiscal multipliers may be larger when targeted to liquidity-constrained households.
Because excess sensitivity implies consumption is unresponsive to transfers.
Because it proves that monetary policy is ineffective.
Because it eliminates any role for automatic stabilizers.
questions.correctAnswer: Because if markets are incomplete, fiscal multipliers may be larger when targeted to liquidity-constrained households.
questions.explanation: Heterogeneous agents with MPC heterogeneity shape the incidence and size of multipliers.

questions.questionText: Which policy mix best handles a sudden food-price spike while protecting the poor and preserving production incentives?
options: Broad export bans and universal consumption subsidies.
Temporary targeted transfers (or food vouchers), time-limited tariff relief on key staples, and commitments not to impose export bans to stabilize expectations for farmers.
Price controls for all food items enforced indefinitely.
Permanent VAT exemptions for all food regardless of incidence.
questions.correctAnswer: Temporary targeted transfers (or food vouchers), time-limited tariff relief on key staples, and commitments not to impose export bans to stabilize expectations for farmers.
questions.explanation: Targeting cushions vulnerable households while preserving incentives for supply response.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes the Atkinson index from the Gini for policy analysis?
options: The Atkinson index incorporates explicit inequality aversion through a parameter, allowing welfare-consistent comparisons; the Gini does not embed a normative parameter.
Both are identical measures with different names.
The Gini is always more sensitive to the bottom tail than Atkinson.
Atkinson can only be used with grouped data.
questions.correctAnswer: The Atkinson index incorporates explicit inequality aversion through a parameter, allowing welfare-consistent comparisons; the Gini does not embed a normative parameter.
questions.explanation: Varying epsilon changes sensitivity to different parts of the distribution and links to social welfare.

questions.questionText: A growth incidence curve lies everywhere above zero and is upward-sloping. What does this imply for inclusiveness?
options: All quantiles gained, but higher quantiles gained more; poverty likely fell, while inequality may have risen.
Only the rich gained; poverty rose.
Only the poor gained; inequality increased.
Average income fell despite positive quantile growth.
questions.correctAnswer: All quantiles gained, but higher quantiles gained more; poverty likely fell, while inequality may have risen.
questions.explanation: Positive growth at all points reduces poverty if the line is fixed, but a steeper profile raises dispersion.

questions.questionText: How should DSGE and reduced-form evidence be combined in policy design for inclusive stabilization?
options: Use DSGE models only; reduced-form evidence is anecdotal.
Calibrate and discipline structural models with reduced-form elasticities and causal estimates for key wedges, then test distributional implications in the model.
Use reduced-form estimates only; models add no value.
Choose whichever approach supports the preferred policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Calibrate and discipline structural models with reduced-form elasticities and causal estimates for key wedges, then test distributional implications in the model.
questions.explanation: Structural coherence plus credible magnitudes yields better ex ante and ex post evaluation.

questions.questionText: In instrumental-variables estimation, what does the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) identify?
options: The average treatment effect for the entire population regardless of compliance behavior.
The causal effect for compliers whose treatment status is changed by the instrument under monotonicity and exclusion.
The intention-to-treat effect for never-takers.
The effect for always-takers only.
questions.correctAnswer: The causal effect for compliers whose treatment status is changed by the instrument under monotonicity and exclusion.
questions.explanation: IV recovers a local effect for the subgroup induced to change treatment by the instrument, not a universal ATE.

questions.questionText: How can machine-learning-assisted tax enforcement support inclusion without sacrificing legitimacy?
options: By optimizing black-box models that cannot be audited to maximize assessed liabilities.
By using interpretable models with fairness and due-process safeguards, targeting high-risk cases while monitoring for disparate impacts and providing avenues for redress.
By assigning audits randomly to avoid any bias.
By focusing only on low-income taxpayers because they are numerous.
questions.correctAnswer: By using interpretable models with fairness and due-process safeguards, targeting high-risk cases while monitoring for disparate impacts and providing avenues for redress.
questions.explanation: Transparency, accountability, and bias checks preserve trust while improving compliance and fiscal space.

questions.questionText: Hsieh–Klenow style exercises infer misallocation from dispersion in marginal revenue products across firms. What is the most defensible policy interpretation when dispersion is large within narrowly defined industries?
options: High dispersion necessarily reflects technological heterogeneity, so there is no role for policy.

Large dispersion suggests wedges in credit, input, or regulatory markets that prevent resources from flowing to more productive firms; easing entry, improving finance, and simplifying compliance can raise aggregate TFP.
Dispersion proves that competition policy should mandate identical market shares for all firms to equalize marginal products.
Dispersion arises only from measurement error, so policies should ignore it even if persistent across datasets.
questions.correctAnswer: Large dispersion suggests wedges in credit, input, or regulatory markets that prevent resources from flowing to more productive firms; easing entry, improving finance, and simplifying compliance can raise aggregate TFP.
questions.explanation: Persistent within-industry dispersion signals barriers to reallocation; reducing wedges can lift TFP without new technology.

questions.questionText: What is the main lesson from management practice experiments (for example, intensive consulting to randomly selected plants) for inclusive growth strategies?
options: Managerial practices are pure window dressing; they never affect productivity or employment.

Improving basic management systems can raise productivity and quality, but diffusion is slow without complementary competition, skills, and information; policy should address these diffusion frictions.
Only foreign-owned plants respond to management improvements because domestic firms lack absorptive capacity in principle.
Management upgrades reduce productivity by constraining entrepreneurial freedom and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Improving basic management systems can raise productivity and quality, but diffusion is slow without complementary competition, skills, and information; policy should address these diffusion frictions.
questions.explanation: Evidence shows sizable gains in treated firms and slow spillovers; diffusion needs market and policy supports.

questions.questionText: In the Harris–Todaro framework, which policy bundle most directly reduces urban open unemployment without suppressing overall productivity?
options: Ban rural-urban migration and fix urban wages permanently above market-clearing levels.
Lower barriers to formal hiring, expand urban job search efficiency, and raise rural productivity so expected earnings equalize with less queuing.
Introduce universal public employment in cities regardless of skills or tasks.
Subsidize urban consumption to attract even more migrants so unemployment measures look smaller as a share of population.
questions.correctAnswer: Lower barriers to formal hiring, expand urban job search efficiency, and raise rural productivity so expected earnings equalize with less queuing.
questions.explanation: Expected income equalization means easing matching frictions and improving rural earnings reduces urban queuing.

questions.questionText: What is the Lewis turning point and why does it matter for wage dynamics?
options: It is the moment when agriculture becomes more productive than industry, forcing deindustrialization.
It is when the surplus labor pool is exhausted and the marginal product of labor in agriculture rises, after which further industrial expansion requires higher real wages.
It is when a country fixes its exchange rate and labor markets clear at zero unemployment.
It is the date when population growth peaks and wages stop changing thereafter.
questions.correctAnswer: It is when the surplus labor pool is exhausted and the marginal product of labor in agriculture rises, after which further industrial expansion requires higher real wages.
questions.explanation: Once cheap labor is exhausted, wage growth accelerates and the distributional and competitiveness landscape shifts.

questions.questionText: How does task polarization interact with development and services tradability in shaping inclusive growth?
options: Because only manufacturing is tradable, services cannot generate inclusive growth.

Automation and offshoring can reduce middle-skill routine jobs while high-skill and some low-skill personal services expand; making services more tradable via digital connectivity can broaden opportunities.
Polarization always increases middle-class employment by boosting routine tasks.
Services tradability automatically guarantees equal wage growth across the distribution.
questions.correctAnswer: Automation and offshoring can reduce middle-skill routine jobs while high-skill and some low-skill personal services expand; making services more tradable via digital connectivity can broaden opportunities.
questions.explanation: Policy that enables exportable services and skills adaptation can offset routine-biased displacement.

questions.questionText: Under which conditions are foreign direct investment spillovers most likely to raise domestic firm productivity?
options: When domestic firms are barred from supplier relationships to avoid collusion.
When absorptive capacity is adequate, linkages are dense, competition policy prevents foreclosure, and skills and standards allow learning-by-supplying.
When multinationals receive unconditional tax holidays with no local linkages.
When technology is obsolete, so domestic imitation is easier.
questions.correctAnswer: When absorptive capacity is adequate, linkages are dense, competition policy prevents foreclosure, and skills and standards allow learning-by-supplying.
questions.explanation: Spillovers depend on capability, contestability, and deliberate linkage policies, not on presence alone.

questions.questionText: How can a government support exporters without violating efficiency principles embedded in VAT systems?
options: By prohibiting input tax credits to prevent revenue leakage.
By zero-rating exports and promptly refunding input VAT to exporters while keeping domestic VAT broad-based.
By exempting all firms that export at least one product from paying any VAT on domestic sales.
By taxing exports at a higher VAT rate to raise revenue from foreign consumers.
questions.correctAnswer: By zero-rating exports and promptly refunding input VAT to exporters while keeping domestic VAT broad-based.
questions.explanation: Destination-based VAT zero-rates exports and refunds input credits to avoid cascading and preserve neutrality.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes monetary dominance from fiscal dominance in macroeconomic regimes, and why does it matter for inclusive stabilization?
options: Under monetary dominance, fiscal policy sets interest rates; under fiscal dominance, the central bank sets taxes.

Under monetary dominance, the central bank can stabilize inflation because fiscal policy is consistent with its target; under fiscal dominance, financing needs force monetization or default risks that undermine price stability and hurt the poor.
Monetary dominance applies only in fixed exchange rate regimes, while fiscal dominance applies only under floats.
The distinction is semantic and has no policy relevance.
questions.correctAnswer: Under monetary dominance, the central bank can stabilize inflation because fiscal policy is consistent with its target; under fiscal dominance, financing needs force monetization or default risks that undermine price stability and hurt the poor.
questions.explanation: Credible fiscal backing is required for monetary anchors; instability is regressive.

questions.questionText: Which statement best characterizes sovereign spread dynamics for emerging markets?
options: Spreads are determined entirely by global risk appetite and ignore domestic fundamentals.
Spreads reflect both global financial conditions and country-specific fundamentals such as debt composition, fiscal credibility, growth prospects, and institutional quality.
Spreads can be permanently fixed by pegging the exchange rate to a reserve currency.
Spreads always fall when commodity prices rise, regardless of policy.
questions.correctAnswer: Spreads reflect both global financial conditions and country-specific fundamentals such as debt composition, fiscal credibility, growth prospects, and institutional quality.
questions.explanation: Global push factors and domestic pull factors jointly drive borrowing costs and resilience.

questions.questionText: How can social insurance expand entrepreneurship without reducing efficiency?
options: By guaranteeing profits for all new firms regardless of performance.
By reducing catastrophic downside risk for households (for example, health shocks), which raises risk-bearing capacity and entry where expected returns are positive.
By prohibiting wage employment to encourage self-employment.
By mandating equal market shares across all startups.
questions.correctAnswer: By reducing catastrophic downside risk for households (for example, health shocks), which raises risk-bearing capacity and entry where expected returns are positive.
questions.explanation: Smoothing idiosyncratic risk can loosen liquidity and risk constraints and improve occupational choice.

questions.questionText: Which empirical mistake most clearly risks a 'bad control' bias in causal estimation?
options: Controlling for pre-treatment covariates that predict treatment but are not affected by it.
Controlling for a post-treatment mediator that lies on the causal path from treatment to outcome.
Using fixed effects in a panel to remove time-invariant heterogeneity.
Clustering standard errors at the treatment-unit level.
questions.correctAnswer: Controlling for a post-treatment mediator that lies on the causal path from treatment to outcome.
questions.explanation: Conditioning on a mediator blocks part of the treatment effect and can induce bias via collider paths.

questions.questionText: What is a key limitation to watch in synthetic control applications?
options: The method permits negative weights, which makes interpretation difficult.
Poor pre-treatment fit or heavy reliance on extrapolation undermines credibility; inference should use placebo tests to assess uniqueness of the effect.
It cannot handle more than two donor regions.
It eliminates the need for any qualitative institutional knowledge.
questions.correctAnswer: Poor pre-treatment fit or heavy reliance on extrapolation undermines credibility; inference should use placebo tests to assess uniqueness of the effect.
questions.explanation: SC is strongest when donors can approximate the treated unit pre-treatment and placebo gaps are small.

questions.questionText: A local minimum wage increase shows no employment loss in treated firms. Which concern must be addressed before concluding there is no disemployment effect overall?
options: General equilibrium adjustments and spillovers could shift employment to untreated firms or areas; evaluation must capture broader labor-market responses.
Measurement error in wages always biases results toward finding no effect.
The result proves monopsony power is absent in the local labor market.
Any positive wage effect implies rising unemployment by identity.
questions.correctAnswer: General equilibrium adjustments and spillovers could shift employment to untreated firms or areas; evaluation must capture broader labor-market responses.
questions.explanation: Displacement, substitution, and demand responses can mask effects in narrow samples.

questions.questionText: When appraising adaptation projects such as flood protection, which approach best handles distributional and intergenerational concerns?
options: Use market interest rates only and ignore equity weights.
Apply cost–benefit analysis with sensitivity to declining discount rates for long horizons and consider equity weights where benefits accrue disproportionately to vulnerable groups.
Reject cost–benefit analysis entirely and approve all projects with vocal support.
Use a zero discount rate for all future benefits and costs regardless of time horizon.
questions.correctAnswer: Apply cost–benefit analysis with sensitivity to declining discount rates for long horizons and consider equity weights where benefits accrue disproportionately to vulnerable groups.
questions.explanation: Long horizons and vulnerable beneficiaries justify careful discounting and equity-sensitive evaluation.

questions.questionText: Which practice ensures consistent valuation of time savings and safety in transport cost–benefit analysis?
options: Use arbitrary values that vary by project to reflect local politics.
Apply standardized values of time and a value of statistical life consistent with national guidelines, and test sensitivity to income growth and distributional weights.
Ignore time savings because they are intangible.
Count time savings only for motorists and not for public transport users.
questions.correctAnswer: Apply standardized values of time and a value of statistical life consistent with national guidelines, and test sensitivity to income growth and distributional weights.
questions.explanation: Consistent shadow pricing improves comparability and fairness; sensitivity tests capture uncertainty.

questions.questionText: How do spatial inequality metrics complement interpersonal inequality measures for policy design?
options: They are redundant because the Gini coefficient already captures geography.
Between-area decompositions (for example, Theil between components) reveal place-based gaps that may require spatially targeted policies in addition to nationwide transfers.
Spatial metrics focus only on housing prices and thus miss income differences.
They are useful only in countries without migration.
questions.correctAnswer: Between-area decompositions (for example, Theil between components) reveal place-based gaps that may require spatially targeted policies in addition to nationwide transfers.
questions.explanation: Place effects and interpersonal dispersion are distinct; both inform inclusive policy.

questions.questionText: What VAT design feature reduces compliance costs for micro-firms while protecting the base?
options: A very high registration threshold with no enforcement on larger firms.
A simplified presumptive regime for small taxpayers alongside a standard VAT for larger firms, coupled with timely refunds for exporters.
Exempting all services from VAT to reduce paperwork.
Applying multiple rates to tailor distributional aims at the register.
questions.correctAnswer: A simplified presumptive regime for small taxpayers alongside a standard VAT for larger firms, coupled with timely refunds for exporters.
questions.explanation: Simplification at the bottom and integrity at the top limit distortions and leakages.

questions.questionText: Why do complex rules of origin often blunt the benefits of preferential trade agreements for low-capacity exporters?
options: They guarantee higher preference margins by design.
They raise compliance costs and uncertainty, causing firms to forgo preferences and pay MFN tariffs; simpler, widely used rules can increase utilization.
They apply only to large firms and therefore are irrelevant for small exporters.
They make domestic content cheaper, so firms always benefit.
questions.correctAnswer: They raise compliance costs and uncertainty, causing firms to forgo preferences and pay MFN tariffs; simpler, widely used rules can increase utilization.
questions.explanation: Administrative barriers can be binding even when tariff preferences look attractive on paper.

questions.questionText: What is the main applied difference between PPP-based, FEER, and BEER approaches to assessing exchange-rate misalignment?
options: PPP and FEER are identical because both use only prices.

PPP compares absolute price levels ignoring fundamentals; FEER sets the rate consistent with internal and external balance; BEER estimates equilibrium from econometric relationships with fundamentals.
BEER is a literary theory unrelated to exchange rates; PPP and FEER are the only valid tools.
FEER assumes capital controls and cannot be used in open economies.
questions.correctAnswer: PPP compares absolute price levels ignoring fundamentals; FEER sets the rate consistent with internal and external balance; BEER estimates equilibrium from econometric relationships with fundamentals.
questions.explanation: Different lenses serve different policy questions; none is definitive in isolation.

questions.questionText: How can payroll tax design avoid discouraging formal job creation while preserving social insurance?
options: Set very high uniform payroll rates and exempt large firms.
Phase in contributions for new formal jobs or low-wage workers, finance part of benefits from general revenue, and simplify compliance to reduce fixed costs.
Eliminate employer contributions and fund social insurance solely with VAT.
Tax informal employment at the same rate through random audits alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Phase in contributions for new formal jobs or low-wage workers, finance part of benefits from general revenue, and simplify compliance to reduce fixed costs.
questions.explanation: Targeted design and low administrative barriers can raise formality without eroding insurance.

questions.questionText: Which constraint set most plausibly limits worker mobility across regions and sectors, and what policy addresses it?
options: Only preferences limit mobility; policy is irrelevant.
Housing supply constraints, credential recognition barriers, and relocation costs; increasing housing supply near jobs, recognizing qualifications, and offering mobility grants can ease transitions.
High minimum wages alone explain immobility; cutting them is sufficient.
Trade policy determines mobility more than local constraints.
questions.correctAnswer: Housing supply constraints, credential recognition barriers, and relocation costs; increasing housing supply near jobs, recognizing qualifications, and offering mobility grants can ease transitions.
questions.explanation: Spatial frictions and licensing can bind; targeted policies improve matching and equity.

questions.questionText: How should policy interpret evidence that education raises wages partly through signaling and partly through human capital accumulation?
options: If signaling exists, education spending has zero social return.
Even with signaling, substantial human capital effects justify investments, especially where quality improvements raise learning; targeting market failures (credit, information) remains warranted.
Because signaling is present, only vocational training should be funded.
Signaling implies that taxes on education would increase efficiency.
questions.correctAnswer: Even with signaling, substantial human capital effects justify investments, especially where quality improvements raise learning; targeting market failures (credit, information) remains warranted.
questions.explanation: Mixed mechanisms do not negate social returns; policy focuses on learning, access, and efficient financing.

questions.questionText: Index-based drought insurance for smallholders often suffers from basis risk. Which complementary policy most directly mitigates welfare losses from mismatch?
options: Mandate that all payouts be equal regardless of losses.
Combine index insurance with investments in local weather stations and irrigation infrastructure, and layer schemes with social assistance to cover catastrophic gaps.
Eliminate reinsurance so insurers have incentives to monitor fields closely.
Require farmers to buy insurance even when correlations are weak.
questions.correctAnswer: Combine index insurance with investments in local weather stations and irrigation infrastructure, and layer schemes with social assistance to cover catastrophic gaps.
questions.explanation: Improving correlation and providing public backstops reduces underinsurance for vulnerable households.

questions.questionText: What is the most credible way to handle stranded-asset risk for coal power in a just energy transition?
options: Mandate immediate shutdowns without compensation or planning.
Use transparent, time-bound transition contracts (for example, reverse auctions for early retirement), support worker retraining and mobility, and invest in regional diversification.
Offer perpetual subsidies to keep plants operating at low load factors.
Nationalize all assets permanently and continue operations indefinitely.
questions.correctAnswer: Use transparent, time-bound transition contracts (for example, reverse auctions for early retirement), support worker retraining and mobility, and invest in regional diversification.
questions.explanation: Credible decommissioning mechanisms and worker/place support preserve political feasibility and efficiency.

questions.questionText: How can social programs leverage administrative data while protecting privacy and maintaining trust?
options: Link datasets without consent to maximize predictive power.
Use privacy-preserving record linkage, clear legal bases and consent where required, independent audits, and strict access controls; publish impact evidence to demonstrate value.
Share raw personal data with all agencies to reduce duplication.
Rely only on surveys to avoid any data risks.
questions.correctAnswer: Use privacy-preserving record linkage, clear legal bases and consent where required, independent audits, and strict access controls; publish impact evidence to demonstrate value.
questions.explanation: Trustworthy data use combines technical safeguards, legal protections, and transparency about results.

questions.questionText: In growth accounting for developing economies, which interpretation most credibly explains a persistent residual in total factor productivity after careful measurement of capital and labor?
options: It is entirely noise from survey error and can be ignored in policy.
It reflects technology, organization, and misallocation; reforms that improve competition, management, and input reallocation can raise the residual even without new machinery.
It proves that capital is mismeasured and must be doubled in the accounts.
It is driven only by trade openness and not by domestic institutions.
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects technology, organization, and misallocation; reforms that improve competition, management, and input reallocation can raise the residual even without new machinery.
questions.explanation: TFP absorbs technology and efficiency; policy can shift it through better allocation and capabilities.

questions.questionText: Piketty’s r > g condition is often cited in debates on inequality. What is the most defensible economic reading of this relationship for policy?
options: Whenever r exceeds g, wealth concentration must rise mechanically and cannot be countered by policy.
A sustained gap between the after-tax return on wealth and the growth rate can amplify wealth concentration unless offset by taxation, diffusion of ownership, or shocks.
The condition is irrelevant outside rich countries.
If g is low, raising interest rates reduces inequality by increasing savings.
questions.correctAnswer: A sustained gap between the after-tax return on wealth and the growth rate can amplify wealth concentration unless offset by taxation, diffusion of ownership, or shocks.
questions.explanation: Distribution depends on the after-tax return, growth, and shocks—not on a tautology.

questions.questionText: A ministry considers student tracking in lower secondary school. What is the strongest efficiency–equity concern at scale?
options: Tracking always raises average scores by specialization.
Early rigid tracking can lock in disadvantage if measurement is noisy and mobility is low; targeted support and flexible pathways can preserve efficiency while limiting stratification.
Equity concerns vanish if class sizes are small.
Tracking is irrelevant once national exams exist.
questions.correctAnswer: Early rigid tracking can lock in disadvantage if measurement is noisy and mobility is low; targeted support and flexible pathways can preserve efficiency while limiting stratification.
questions.explanation: Noisy signals plus low mobility raise equity costs; design can mitigate them.

questions.questionText: For informal settlements, which package most plausibly improves welfare without triggering large-scale displacement?
options: Immediate relocation to distant sites with no services.
In-situ upgrading of services and tenure security, plus transport connectivity to jobs and risk-informed planning for high-hazard zones.
Title deeds only; services will follow automatically.
A moratorium on any new construction but no enforcement.
questions.correctAnswer: In-situ upgrading of services and tenure security, plus transport connectivity to jobs and risk-informed planning for high-hazard zones.
questions.explanation: Upgrading and access reduce welfare losses and enable gradual formalization.

questions.questionText: Social registries are proposed to target transfers. What is the central inclusion risk to manage?
options: Too many people apply, which is always a waste of funds.
Errors of exclusion—missing vulnerable households in dynamic informal economies—require frequent updates, community verification, and grievance redress.
Errors of inclusion cannot occur if proxy means tests are used.
Registries eliminate the need for appeals or audits.
questions.correctAnswer: Errors of exclusion—missing vulnerable households in dynamic informal economies—require frequent updates, community verification, and grievance redress.
questions.explanation: Dynamic poverty and informality make exclusion errors salient; process design is key.

questions.questionText: Which statement correctly characterizes the Alkire–Foster approach to multidimensional poverty?
options: It is identical to the headcount ratio but for consumption only.
It identifies the poor via a dual cutoff and aggregates intensity and incidence into an adjusted headcount index.
It replaces income poverty entirely and cannot be used with it.
It is a purely ordinal tool with no decomposability.
questions.correctAnswer: It identifies the poor via a dual cutoff and aggregates intensity and incidence into an adjusted headcount index.
questions.explanation: AF combines who is poor and how poor across dimensions and is decomposable.

questions.questionText: Present bias and limited attention affect program take-up. Which design most directly addresses these frictions without heavy paternalism?
options: Replace all cash with in-kind goods.
Use default enrollment with easy opt-out, timely reminders, and commitment options such as soft earmarking or prize-linked savings.
Ban marketing and disclosure to avoid overload.
Raise fines for non-participation in voluntary programs.
questions.correctAnswer: Use default enrollment with easy opt-out, timely reminders, and commitment options such as soft earmarking or prize-linked savings.
questions.explanation: Nudges and commitment devices can respect autonomy and improve choices.

questions.questionText: In incomplete-markets models, why can exchange-rate depreciation be contractionary for poorer households in the short run?
options: Because depreciation always lowers exports.
Tradable price spikes hit consumption baskets with high food and fuel shares and raise debt service on FX-linked liabilities, tightening budgets for liquidity-constrained households.
Because wages are indexed one-for-one to the exchange rate.
Because depreciation eliminates automatic stabilizers.
questions.correctAnswer: Tradable price spikes hit consumption baskets with high food and fuel shares and raise debt service on FX-linked liabilities, tightening budgets for liquidity-constrained households.
questions.explanation: Pass-through and balance-sheet channels interact with MPC heterogeneity.

questions.questionText: Which tax feature commonly depresses secondary earners’ labor supply and what is the inclusive fix?
options: Individual filing with low marginal rates; fix by joint filing.
Joint taxation with high implicit marginal tax rates on the second earner; move toward individual filing or credits that reduce the participation tax rate.
Payroll taxes; raise them for primary earners.
VAT; exempt services used by men.
questions.correctAnswer: Joint taxation with high implicit marginal tax rates on the second earner; move toward individual filing or credits that reduce the participation tax rate.
questions.explanation: Lower participation wedges can raise female labor supply and household income.

questions.questionText: What is a realistic advantage and limitation of blended finance for climate projects in lower-income countries?
options: It guarantees market-rate funding for all projects without subsidies.
Concessional funds can de-risk early investments and crowd in private capital, but weak pipelines and governance can limit scale and risk shifting.
It eliminates the need for project appraisal.
It works only for mitigation, never for adaptation.
questions.correctAnswer: Concessional funds can de-risk early investments and crowd in private capital, but weak pipelines and governance can limit scale and risk shifting.
questions.explanation: Blending helps where externalities and risk deter private capital, but institutions matter.

questions.questionText: Collective action clauses (CACs) in sovereign bonds mainly aim to:
options: Lower the interest rate by law in all future contracts.
Facilitate coordinated restructuring by allowing supermajority approval to bind all holders, reducing holdout risks.
Guarantee that defaults cannot occur.
Exempt sovereigns from disclosure rules.
questions.correctAnswer: Facilitate coordinated restructuring by allowing supermajority approval to bind all holders, reducing holdout risks.
questions.explanation: CACs ease orderly workouts and deter disruptive holdouts.

questions.questionText: Time-inconsistency in stabilization policy motivates which institutional design and why?
options: Politicized credit allocation to favor targeted sectors.
Independent monetary policy with clear mandates and accountability to anchor expectations against short-run temptations.
Frequent discretionary fiscal packages with no rules.
Fixed exchange rates backed by secret reserves.
questions.correctAnswer: Independent monetary policy with clear mandates and accountability to anchor expectations against short-run temptations.
questions.explanation: Rules and independence address dynamic inconsistency and improve anchors.

questions.questionText: Why might the Palma ratio complement the Gini in inequality analysis?
options: It equals the Gini squared and is redundant.
It focuses on the tails—the income share of the top 10 percent relative to the bottom 40 percent—highlighting changes the Gini can mute.
It measures poverty rather than inequality.
It cannot be computed from survey data.
questions.correctAnswer: It focuses on the tails—the income share of the top 10 percent relative to the bottom 40 percent—highlighting changes the Gini can mute.
questions.explanation: Tail sensitivity can inform distribution-focused policy choices.

questions.questionText: Evidence from mobile money expansions often shows what pattern for vulnerable households?
options: Lower savings and higher volatility of consumption.
Greater ability to smooth shocks and higher savings via reduced transfer frictions, especially for women.
No change in financial behavior but higher inflation.
A collapse in informal risk-sharing networks with no benefits.
questions.correctAnswer: Greater ability to smooth shocks and higher savings via reduced transfer frictions, especially for women.
questions.explanation: Lower transaction costs and reach improve risk sharing and savings access.

questions.questionText: Which sequencing most plausibly raises welfare in informal settlements vulnerable to floods?
options: Full titling first, then infrastructure later.
Risk mapping and basic services, safe-site development, then conditional tenure regularization aligned with hazard management.
Immediate demolition without alternatives.
Credit subsidies to build in place regardless of hazard.
questions.correctAnswer: Risk mapping and basic services, safe-site development, then conditional tenure regularization aligned with hazard management.
questions.explanation: Aligning tenure with risk management avoids locking households into exposure.

questions.questionText: Which export-promotion instrument has the strongest evidence of cost-effective impacts on firm outcomes?
options: Across-the-board export subsidies tied to domestic content.
Well-governed export promotion agencies that provide information, matchmaking, and standards assistance to first-time exporters.
Permanent tariff rebates on all inputs regardless of export status.
Foreign-exchange rationing to prioritize exporters.
questions.correctAnswer: Well-governed export promotion agencies that provide information, matchmaking, and standards assistance to first-time exporters.
questions.explanation: Overcoming information and network gaps is cheaper and more effective than blunt subsidies.

questions.questionText: What is the consensus from modern immigration economics about effects on native wages?
options: Large, permanent declines for all natives.
Small average effects, with distribution depending on skill complementarity and local adjustment; investment and specialization can offset short-run pressures.
Always positive due to agglomeration economies.
Impossible to estimate because migrants do not work.
questions.correctAnswer: Small average effects, with distribution depending on skill complementarity and local adjustment; investment and specialization can offset short-run pressures.
questions.explanation: Heterogeneity matters; capital and task adjustments moderate impacts.

questions.questionText: Why might a carbon price corridor (price floor and ceiling) be superior to a pure tax or pure cap in some settings?
options: It fixes emissions and prices exactly at the same time.
It provides emissions incentives while limiting price volatility, improving investment planning and political durability.
It eliminates the need for monitoring emissions.
It guarantees revenues will rise each year.
questions.correctAnswer: It provides emissions incentives while limiting price volatility, improving investment planning and political durability.
questions.explanation: Hybrid designs trade off cost certainty and environmental certainty.

questions.questionText: For climate risk in agriculture, how should insurance and social protection be integrated?
options: Insurance alone is sufficient for catastrophic droughts.
Layer parametric micro-insurance for moderate shocks with scalable social assistance for catastrophic events and invest in risk reduction to lower expected losses.
Use only in-kind food aid after shocks.
Rely on credit markets to self-insure households.
questions.correctAnswer: Layer parametric micro-insurance for moderate shocks with scalable social assistance for catastrophic events and invest in risk reduction to lower expected losses.
questions.explanation: Different layers handle different return periods; prevention complements transfers.

questions.questionText: What governance feature most improves state-owned enterprise performance in network utilities?
options: Political appointment of managers without performance contracts.
Independent boards, transparent performance contracts with measurable targets, and hard budget constraints enforced by the finance ministry or regulator.
Unlimited subsidies to guarantee universal access.
Full ministerial micromanagement of daily operations.
questions.correctAnswer: Independent boards, transparent performance contracts with measurable targets, and hard budget constraints enforced by the finance ministry or regulator.
questions.explanation: Autonomy with accountability raises efficiency and service quality.

questions.questionText: Which statement best links health shocks to poverty traps and inclusive growth?
options: Medical shocks are idiosyncratic and never move households across poverty lines.
Large out-of-pocket health expenses can force asset sales and school withdrawals; universal coverage and risk pooling protect human capital and prevent descents into chronic poverty.
Health spending is purely consumption and unrelated to growth.
Private insurance always covers the poor.
questions.correctAnswer: Large out-of-pocket health expenses can force asset sales and school withdrawals; universal coverage and risk pooling protect human capital and prevent descents into chronic poverty.
questions.explanation: Insurance preserves assets and schooling, supporting future productivity.

questions.questionText: How do taste-based and statistical discrimination differ for policy design?
options: They are identical; policy cannot distinguish them.

Taste-based reflects preferences/animus; statistical arises from information gaps; remedies include enforcement and transparency, plus better information and screening to reduce reliance on group averages.
Statistical discrimination is illegal while taste-based is not.
Only taste-based discrimination affects employment.
questions.correctAnswer: Taste-based reflects preferences/animus; statistical arises from information gaps; remedies include enforcement and transparency, plus better information and screening to reduce reliance on group averages.
questions.explanation: Different mechanisms imply different mixes of enforcement and information policy.

questions.questionText: What is a plausible distributional effect of rapid AI diffusion without complementary policies?
options: Uniform wage gains across the entire distribution.
Higher demand for skills complementary to AI and potential displacement of routine tasks, widening wage gaps unless skills, mobility, and competition policies diffuse gains.
Immediate elimination of all low-skill jobs with no offset.
AI reduces productivity so wages fall for everyone.
questions.correctAnswer: Higher demand for skills complementary to AI and potential displacement of routine tasks, widening wage gaps unless skills, mobility, and competition policies diffuse gains.
questions.explanation: Task complementarity and diffusion shape incidence; policy can broaden benefits.

questions.questionText: Default enrollment in retirement savings increased contributions. What pitfall should policymakers watch for before scaling?
options: Default effects are permanent and cannot backfire.
Liquidity-constrained workers may suffer welfare losses if defaults are too high; safe harbors, opt-out ease, and auto-escalation with guardrails manage heterogeneity.
Auto-enrollment eliminates the need for consumer protection.
Defaults work only for high-income workers.
questions.correctAnswer: Liquidity-constrained workers may suffer welfare losses if defaults are too high; safe harbors, opt-out ease, and auto-escalation with guardrails manage heterogeneity.
questions.explanation: Design must respect heterogeneity in liquidity needs and preferences.

questions.questionText: Cluster randomized trials are used to evaluate community programs. What is the key identification risk if interference is likely?
options: There is no risk; SUTVA never fails at the cluster level.
Spillovers across clusters can bias estimates; designs should increase buffer zones, measure spillovers, or use two-stage randomized saturation to estimate both direct and indirect effects.
Clustering makes standard errors too small by definition.
Interference is identical to measurement error and can be ignored.
questions.correctAnswer: Spillovers across clusters can bias estimates; designs should increase buffer zones, measure spillovers, or use two-stage randomized saturation to estimate both direct and indirect effects.
questions.explanation: Violations of SUTVA require designs that identify and account for interference.

questions.questionText: Why can real exchange rate undervaluation work, if at all, as a second-best industrial policy rather than a general recipe for growth?
options: It uniformly raises all sectors’ productivity by making domestic inputs cheaper in real terms, so it is first best.
A mildly undervalued currency can shift resources toward tradables with learning externalities, but sustained large misalignment invites inflation, retaliation, and resource misallocation.
Undervaluation eliminates the need for export logistics because price signals dominate infrastructure gaps.
It guarantees permanent current-account surpluses even when fiscal deficits are large.
questions.correctAnswer: A mildly undervalued currency can shift resources toward tradables with learning externalities, but sustained large misalignment invites inflation, retaliation, and resource misallocation.
questions.explanation: As a second-best, temporary undervaluation can target externalities, but it is not a free lunch and carries macro and political costs.

questions.questionText: In designing public–private partnerships for infrastructure, which risk allocation principle most improves value for money without endangering bankability?
options: Assign all risks to the private partner to maximize incentives, regardless of who controls them.
Allocate each risk to the party best able to manage or price it, with transparent contingent liabilities and credible termination rules.
Keep all demand risk on the public balance sheet to reduce user charges in every case.
Use off–balance sheet treatment to hide fiscal commitments so projects appear cheaper.
questions.correctAnswer: Allocate each risk to the party best able to manage or price it, with transparent contingent liabilities and credible termination rules.
questions.explanation: Efficient risk transfer plus fiscal transparency prevents moral hazard and surprise burdens on the state.

questions.questionText: What is the most defensible welfare interpretation of congestion pricing in large cities when equity is a concern?
options: It is efficient but always regressive, so it should not be used.
Pricing internalizes the congestion externality; earmarking revenues for public transport, low-income rebates, and peripheral connectivity can offset regressivity and raise net welfare.
Pricing is unnecessary because new roads eliminate congestion permanently.
It should be applied only at night to avoid burdening commuters.
questions.correctAnswer: Pricing internalizes the congestion externality; earmarking revenues for public transport, low-income rebates, and peripheral connectivity can offset regressivity and raise net welfare.
questions.explanation: Design and revenue use determine distributional outcomes for efficient instruments.

questions.questionText: A statistical office considers using night-time lights as a proxy for subnational GDP. What is the master’s-level caveat that should guide its deployment?
options: Night lights directly measure productivity, so no calibration is needed.
They provide useful variation where surveys are weak, but saturation, rural bias, and electricity access differences require careful calibration and validation with ground data.
They are superior to firm surveys in all sectors, including agriculture.
They remove the need for national accounts once satellite data are available.
questions.correctAnswer: They provide useful variation where surveys are weak, but saturation, rural bias, and electricity access differences require careful calibration and validation with ground data.
questions.explanation: Remote sensing complements, but does not replace, conventional statistics and needs context-specific correction.

questions.questionText: What is the central economic rationale for spectrum auctions that use simultaneous multiple-round ascending formats with activity rules?
options: They minimize collusion by revealing complete information on bidders’ identities in real time.
They discover prices for interdependent licenses, encourage truthful demand revelation, and reduce exposure risk through package bidding or activity constraints.
They guarantee the lowest possible prices for consumers by capping bids.
They eliminate the need for competition policy in telecommunications.
questions.correctAnswer: They discover prices for interdependent licenses, encourage truthful demand revelation, and reduce exposure risk through package bidding or activity constraints.
questions.explanation: Design features address complementarities and strategic behavior to allocate scarce spectrum efficiently.

questions.questionText: Which combination most plausibly reduces carbon leakage under unilateral climate policy while maintaining efficiency?
options: Permanent exemptions for all energy-intensive trade-exposed sectors.
Border adjustments paired with domestic carbon pricing, time-bound free allocation during transition, and support for low-carbon process innovation.
Setting a lower carbon price for exporters and a higher one for import-competing firms.
Banning imports from countries without identical carbon policies regardless of WTO rules.
questions.correctAnswer: Border adjustments paired with domestic carbon pricing, time-bound free allocation during transition, and support for low-carbon process innovation.
questions.explanation: Leakage falls when incentives are aligned on both borders and production technologies evolve.

questions.questionText: In emerging markets, what is the main macro trade-off of large, sustained FX interventions that are sterilized?
options: They have no costs because sterilization perfectly offsets money growth.
They can stabilize exchange rates in the short run but create quasi-fiscal costs, maturity mismatches, and carry losses that undermine credibility if persistent.
They guarantee lower inflation by definition, independent of fiscal policy.
They eliminate currency mismatches on private balance sheets automatically.
questions.correctAnswer: They can stabilize exchange rates in the short run but create quasi-fiscal costs, maturity mismatches, and carry losses that undermine credibility if persistent.
questions.explanation: Sterilized intervention is not free; balance-sheet risks matter for sustainability and expectations.

questions.questionText: Why can timely VAT refunds to exporters be growth-enhancing even though they reduce cash inflows to the treasury today?
options: Refunds lower the VAT rate on domestic sales, boosting consumption.
They preserve VAT neutrality by preventing tax cascading, supporting working capital and competitiveness in value chains.
They signal favoritism toward large firms, which increases FDI flows.
They allow the state to accumulate arrears that function like short-term debt.
questions.correctAnswer: They preserve VAT neutrality by preventing tax cascading, supporting working capital and competitiveness in value chains.
questions.explanation: Export zero-rating without timely refunds undermines neutrality and harms liquidity-constrained firms.

questions.questionText: Which empirical strategy best isolates the impact of infrastructure upgrades on firm productivity when placement is non-random and favors growing areas?
options: Before–after comparisons in treated corridors only.
Event studies around plausibly exogenous assignment rules or lotteries; or IV using engineering discontinuities, combined with firm-level panels to control for trends.
Cross-sectional regressions of productivity levels on distance to the highway.
Matching treated firms to controls on observable size and sector alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Event studies around plausibly exogenous assignment rules or lotteries; or IV using engineering discontinuities, combined with firm-level panels to control for trends.
questions.explanation: Credible identification must address selection into treatment and dynamic trends.

questions.questionText: In the context of digital platforms with strong network effects, which policy mix protects competition without killing scale economies?
options: Prohibit acquisitions by platforms under any circumstances.
Ensure data portability and interoperability, prohibit self-preferencing that forecloses rivals, and use conduct remedies before breakup where efficiencies from scale are large.
Set uniform price caps on all platform services regardless of cost.
Rely exclusively on ex post antitrust litigation and avoid any ex ante rules.
questions.correctAnswer: Ensure data portability and interoperability, prohibit self-preferencing that forecloses rivals, and use conduct remedies before breakup where efficiencies from scale are large.
questions.explanation: Targeted conduct rules can preserve contestability while respecting scale advantages.

questions.questionText: When does aid fungibility most threaten the additionality of social spending, and what institutional fix helps?
options: When donors finance discrete projects with separate accounts; additionality is automatic.

When budgets are soft and line ministries can reallocate domestic funds away from aided sectors; medium-term expenditure frameworks with transparent ceilings and joint monitoring strengthen additionality.
When debt levels are low; fungibility is then irrelevant.
When aid is on-budget; integration eliminates all governance concerns.
questions.correctAnswer: When budgets are soft and line ministries can reallocate domestic funds away from aided sectors; medium-term expenditure frameworks with transparent ceilings and joint monitoring strengthen additionality.
questions.explanation: Rules and transparency reduce substitution and align domestic and external resources.

questions.questionText: Which argument best supports GDP-linked (state-contingent) sovereign debt from an inclusive growth perspective?
options: It lowers borrowing costs in all states of the world by fixing coupons.
Payments that fall in bad times and rise in good times stabilize fiscal policy and social spending, reducing procyclical cuts that hit vulnerable groups.
It eliminates the need for debt sustainability analysis.
It prevents exchange-rate risk on all liabilities.
questions.correctAnswer: Payments that fall in bad times and rise in good times stabilize fiscal policy and social spending, reducing procyclical cuts that hit vulnerable groups.
questions.explanation: State contingency shares risk with investors and can protect core programs during downturns.

questions.questionText: Rigorous evaluations of ed-tech interventions often find limited average effects. What design feature most plausibly turns ed-tech into a productivity-enhancing input?
options: Device provision without curriculum integration to maximize autonomy.
Personalized learning software aligned with pedagogy, real-time feedback for teachers, and complementary coaching rather than devices alone.
Eliminating teacher training to avoid crowding out technology.
Using the same content for all grades to standardize delivery.
